장소 (Places).example_en: In summer, children play at the fountain.
장소 (Places).notes: 분수 (fountain) + 대 (platform/stand). Many Korean parks have 분수대 where children play in summer.

장소 (Places).example_en: There is a beautiful garden at my grandmother's house.
장소 (Places).notes: 庭園 from Chinese characters. Can refer to private gardens or public gardens. 한국 정원 (Korean garden) has a distinctive natural style.

장소 (Places).example_en: In Seoul, there are many apartments and few houses.
장소 (Places).notes: 住宅 meaning 'dwelling.' More formal than 집. 단독주택 means 'detached house,' 다가구주택 means 'multi-family house.'

장소 (Places).example: 저 빌딩은 몇 층이에요? 정말 높아요.
장소 (Places).example_en: How many floors does that building have? It's really tall.
장소 (Places).notes: From English 'building.' Usually refers to tall commercial or office buildings. Residential buildings are more commonly called 아파트 or 건물.

장소 (Places).example_en: I lived in a rooftop room when I was a college student.
장소 (Places).notes: A small room built on a building's rooftop, often the cheapest housing option. Made famous by Korean dramas as the home of struggling protagonists.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a bank on the left.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 왼 = left + 쪽 = side/direction. 왼손 = left hand.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go to the right.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 오른 = right + 쪽 = side/direction. 오른손 = right hand.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Let's meet in front of the school.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Used with 에 or 에서. 앞으로 = forward/from now on.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a parking lot behind the building.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 뒤에 = behind (location). 뒤로 = backward (direction).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a book on top of the desk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 위에 = on top of / above. One of the essential location particles.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a bag under the chair.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 아래에 = below/under. Sometimes shortened to 밑에 which is very similar.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe next to the post office.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 옆에 = next to. 바로 옆에 = right next to.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's between the bank and the pharmacy.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: A 와/과 B 사이에 = between A and B. Also used for relationships: 사이가 좋다 = get along well.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please go inside the building.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 안에 = inside. Opposite of 밖에. 안에서 = from inside.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's raining outside.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 밖에 = outside. 밖에서 = from outside. 밖으로 나가다 = to go outside.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Can I sit here?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Part of the 이/그/저 system: 여기 (here, near me), 거기 (there, near you), 저기 (over there).

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please wait there.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Refers to a place near the listener or a previously mentioned place.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: What's that building you can see over there?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Refers to a place far from both speaker and listener. Often accompanied by pointing.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please come this way.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 이 (this) + 쪽 (direction/side). Very commonly used when guiding someone.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you go that way, there's a station.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 그 (that) + 쪽 (direction). Also a polite way to say 'you' in formal contexts.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The restroom is over that way.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 저 (that far) + 쪽 (direction). Used when pointing to somewhere distant.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: It's close from here.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Adverb form. Adjective: 가깝다 (close). Irregular: 가깝다 → 가까워요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: My home is far from the office.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Adverb form. Adjective: 멀다 (far). Irregular: 멀다 → 멀어요.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a mart across from the bank.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 건너 (to cross) + 편 (side). Same meaning as 맞은편.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe on the opposite side of the station.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 맞은 (facing) + 편 (side). Interchangeable with 건너편 in most cases.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go straight on this road.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 직 (straight) + 진 (advance). Often used in GPS navigation and giving directions.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go right at the intersection.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: ~(으)로 가세요 is the standard pattern for giving directions. 가세요 is polite imperative.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go left at the convenience store.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Same pattern as 오른쪽으로 가세요. Use landmarks as reference points.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Where is the restroom?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Essential question pattern. 어디 = where. Attach the subject with 이/가 before 어디.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Can I go this way?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Also means 'way/path' figuratively. 길을 잃다 = to get lost.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please show me the map.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 지 (land) + 도 (diagram). Most Koreans use 네이버 지도 or 카카오맵 on their phones.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you turn the corner, there's a cafe.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 모퉁이를 돌다 = to turn a corner. 코너 (loanword) is also used.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Go left at the intersection.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 사 (four) + 거리 (street) = four-way intersection. 삼거리 = three-way intersection.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Cross at the crosswalk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 횡단 (crossing) + 보도 (walkway). In casual speech, people sometimes say 건널목.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Come out through exit 3.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 출 (out) + 구 (opening). Subway stations have numbered exits. Great for giving meeting locations.

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Seoul is in the northern part of Korea.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 북 = north (Sino-Korean); 북쪽으로 = toward the north

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Busan is in the south.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 남 = south (Sino-Korean); 남쪽으로 가세요 = go south

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The sun rises in the east.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 동 = east (Sino-Korean); 동해 = East Sea

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The sun sets in the west.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 서 = west (Sino-Korean); 서해 = West Sea

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a fountain in the center of the plaza.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 중 = middle + 앙 = center; 중앙선 = center line

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: There's a cafe at the end of this street.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Also means 'finish': 끝났어요 = it's over/finished

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: I'll explain again from the beginning.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 처음에 = at first; 처음이에요 = it's my first time

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The pharmacy is on the opposite side of the street.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 반대 = opposite + 쪽 = side/direction; useful for giving directions

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please go up the stairs.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 계 = steps + 단 = level; 계단을 내려가다 = to go down stairs

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The elevator is broken.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Loanword from English; also shortened to 엘베 in casual speech

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Take the escalator to this floor.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Loanword from English; common in malls and subway stations

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Is there a bank nearby?
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 근 = near + 처 = place; 근처에 = in the vicinity of

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: The cafe is on the first floor.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: Korean 1층 = ground floor (same as American system, not British)

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: We have to go around because of construction.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 돌다 (to turn) + 아가다; also means 'to pass away' (honorific: 돌아가시다)

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: If you pass the bank, you'll see the school.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 지나다 (to pass) + 가다 (to go); 시간이 지나가다 = time passes

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Just follow this road.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 따르다 (to follow) + 가다 (to go); very useful for directions

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please cross at the crosswalk.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 건너다 (to cross) + 가다 (to go); 길을 건너가다 = to cross the street

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Turn right at the next corner.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 돌다 = to turn/rotate; 왼쪽으로 돌다 = turn left; 한 바퀴 돌다 = go around once

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please place it horizontally.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 가로 = width/horizontal direction; 가로등 = street lamp

방향 & 위치 (Directions).example_en: Please stand it up vertically.
방향 & 위치 (Directions).notes: 세로 = height/vertical direction; opposite of 가로

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This store is really good.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General word for any small shop. More casual than 상점 (商店).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: There are a lot of items.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Refers to physical goods/merchandise. Different from 것 which is more abstract.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Let's go buy a gift.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~(으)러 가다 means 'to go in order to.' 사다 → 사요 (present), 샀어요 (past).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: What do they sell here?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 팔다 → 팔아요. ㄹ irregular: ㄹ drops before ㄴ, ㅂ, ㅅ endings.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The price is a bit expensive.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 가 (price) + 격 (level). More formal than just asking 얼마예요?

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: How much is this?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: The most essential shopping phrase. Works everywhere from markets to department stores.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's too expensive. Please give me a discount.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 비싸다 → 비싸요. Bargaining is common at traditional markets but not at fixed-price stores.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This place is really cheap!
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 싸다 → 싸요. 싸게 사다 = to buy cheaply. Can also mean 'to wrap.'

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Is it on discount?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 할인하다 = to discount. 할인 카드 = discount card. 할인 행사 = discount event/sale.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Is there a sale now?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English. Used interchangeably with 할인 in casual speech.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'd like to exchange the size.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General word for 'to change/exchange.' 바꾸다 → 바꿔요. Also means 'to switch.'

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I get a refund?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 환 (return) + 불 (pay). 환불받다 = to receive a refund. Keep your receipt for refunds.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Is an exchange possible?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 교 (exchange) + 환 (swap). More formal than 바꾸다. Used for store exchanges.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have a different size?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword. Korean sizes may differ from Western sizes. 프리사이즈 = free size (one size fits all).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 이거 좀 커요. 작은 거 있어요?
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This is a bit big. Do you have a small one?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 크다 → 커요. Used for both size and scale. 큰 = big (adjective before nouns).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This one is too small.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 작다 → 작아요. 작은 사이즈 = small size.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have other colors?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Also shortened to 색. 무슨 색깔 좋아해요? = What color do you like?

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Please give me the red one.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 빨간 (red) + 색 (color). The adjective alone is 빨갛다 (to be red).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The blue one is prettier.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 파란 (blue) + 색 (color). The adjective is 파랗다 (to be blue).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have black pants?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 검은 (black) + 색. Also called 까만색 (pure/deep black) in casual speech.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The white one looks the cleanest.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 하얀 (white) + 색. Also 흰색. 하얗다 is the base adjective (to be white).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay by card. Here you go.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~(으)로 할게요 = I'll do it by/with. Very common at checkout counters.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay cash. Do you have change?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 거스름돈 = change (money returned). Some places give a small discount for cash.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you need a bag?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Plastic bags cost money in Korea (usually 50-100 won). Bring your own bag to save.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Receipt, please. I need to submit it to my company.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Some stores ask 영수증 필요하세요? (Do you need a receipt?) at checkout.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I try on this dress?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: ~아/어 봐도 돼요? = may I try ~ing? 입다 = to wear (clothes). 신다 = to wear (shoes).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Excuse me, how much is this?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Point at the item while asking. In markets, items may not have price tags.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 좀 깎아 주세요. 두 개 살게요.
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Please give a discount. I'll buy two.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 깎다 = to cut/shave off. Only use at traditional markets, not at chain stores.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example: 마음에 안 들어요. 다른 거 있어요?
쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I don't like it. Do you have something else?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 다른 = different/other. 마음에 들다 = to like (literally: to enter one's heart).

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I bought new shoes.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Remove shoes when entering Korean homes, some restaurants, and temples.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: There are a lot of pretty clothes.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General term for clothing. 옷가게 = clothing store. 옷을 입다 = to wear clothes.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: These pants are comfortable.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Covers all types: 청바지 (jeans), 반바지 (shorts). Always plural in meaning.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The skirt is too short.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 미니 치마 = mini skirt. 긴 치마 = long skirt. 짧다 = to be short.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: You look cooler when you wear a hat.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 모자를 쓰다 = to wear a hat. 쓰다 is the verb used for hats and glasses.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The bag is heavy.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: General term for any bag: backpack, purse, briefcase. 책가방 = school bag.

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: These days I do a lot of online shopping.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Korea is one of the world's biggest online shopping markets

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: How long does delivery take?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 배 = distribute + 송 = send; 당일 배송 = same-day delivery

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's free shipping for orders over 30,000 won.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 무료 = free of charge; a major factor in Korean online shopping

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The package arrived.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 택 = entrust + 배 = deliver; 택배 기사 = delivery driver

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I ordered it online.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Works for both restaurant and shopping orders

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I put it in the shopping cart.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Used for both physical and online shopping carts

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll pay by card.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 결제하다 = to pay/settle; 결제 완료 = payment complete

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Can I pay by credit card?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 신용 = credit/trust; Korea has very high credit card usage

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: You need to have a balance for a debit card.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Draws directly from bank account; popular among younger Koreans

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: I'll collect the points.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 적립 = accumulate; many Korean stores have point/reward systems

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: If you have a coupon, you get a discount.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Mobile coupons (모바일 쿠폰) are very common in Korea

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: The size doesn't fit so I'd like to exchange it.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 교환 = exchange; different from 환불 (refund)

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Returns are possible within seven days.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 반 = return + 품 = goods; 반품하다 = to return an item

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: This is a defective item. Please exchange it.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 불량 = defective + 품 = product; grounds for a full refund

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It sold out quickly because it was popular.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 품 = goods + 절 = cut off; 품절되다 = to become sold out

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: New arrivals came out today.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 신 = new + 상품 = product; also called 신상 in casual speech

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: It's much cheaper if you buy it secondhand.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: 중고품 = used item; 중고나라, 당근마켓 = popular resale platforms

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: What brand do you like?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Loanword from English; 명품 브랜드 = luxury brand

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: These pants don't fit.
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Useful phrase when shopping for clothes; 큰 사이즈 = bigger size

쇼핑 (Shopping).example_en: Do you have this T-shirt in other colors?
쇼핑 (Shopping).notes: Common question while shopping; 다른 디자인 있어요? = other designs?

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The weather is really nice today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 날씨 is used in everyday conversation; 기후 means 'climate' for long-term patterns.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's too hot in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 덥다 is for weather/temperature. For hot food or drinks, use 뜨겁다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's really cold outside today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 춥다 is for weather/body feeling. For cold objects or drinks, use 차갑다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: When spring comes, the weather is warm.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Can describe weather, clothing, personality, or food temperature.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The breeze is refreshing.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 시원하다 can mean 'cool' for weather or 'refreshing' for cold drinks and breezes.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's raining a lot, so I need an umbrella.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 비 is the noun 'rain.' To say 'it rains,' use 비가 오다 (rain comes).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It will rain tomorrow.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean literally says 'rain comes' rather than 'it rains.' The subject marker 가 attaches to 비.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The first snow has fallen!
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 눈 means both 'snow' and 'eye.' Context makes the meaning clear. 첫눈 = first snow of the season.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It snows a lot in winter.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Same pattern as 비가 오다. You can also say 눈이 내리다 (snow falls), which sounds more literary.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The wind is blowing hard today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 바람 also means 'wish/hope' or 'affair' in different contexts. Here it means wind.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A cool breeze is blowing on the mountain.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 불다 means 'to blow.' It is also used for blowing out candles (촛불을 불다).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sky is clear so I feel good.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 맑다 describes a clear sky or clear water. For sunny weather, 맑은 날씨 is common.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sky is cloudy today.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 흐리다 can also mean 'blurry' or 'dim' when talking about vision or images.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: There are many clouds so the sun isn't visible.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 구름이 끼다 means 'clouds gather/it gets cloudy.'

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: There was a lot of fog this morning.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 안개가 끼다 means 'fog sets in.' Driving in fog: 안개 속에서 운전하다.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A typhoon is coming, so we need to be careful.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korea experiences typhoons mainly in late summer and early fall. 태 comes from 한자 太 (great).

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I didn't bring an umbrella so I got rained on.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 비를 맞다 literally means 'to get hit by rain.' 접이식 우산 = folding umbrella.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: During the rainy season, it rains every day.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 장마철 is the rainy season period, usually late June to mid-July in Korea.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In spring, many flowers bloom.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 봄 is March to May in Korea. 벚꽃 (cherry blossoms) are a famous spring symbol.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I want to go to the sea in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean summer is hot and humid, especially during 장마 (monsoon). June to August.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In autumn, the fall foliage is really beautiful.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 단풍 means 'autumn leaves / fall colors.' 가을 is September to November.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter, you have to wear warm clothes.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korean winters are very cold and dry. December to February.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Today the temperature is 30 degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Korea uses Celsius (섭씨). 영하 means below zero: 영하 5도 = minus 5 degrees.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's too humid in summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 습도 means 'humidity.' Korea's summer humidity can feel oppressive.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter, the air is dry.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 건조하다 is used for weather, skin, or food. 피부가 건조하다 = skin is dry.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The fine dust is bad, so I wear a mask.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: A major concern in Korea, especially in spring. Check 미세먼지 forecasts on weather apps.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The weather forecast said it will be clear tomorrow.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일기 here means 'weather' (not 'diary,' which is the same word). 예보 = forecast.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: When the sun rises, the weather gets warm.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 해 also means 'year.' 해가 뜨다 = sun rises, 해가 지다 = sun sets.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The moon is really bright tonight.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 달 also means 'month.' 보름달 = full moon, 반달 = half moon.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: You can see many stars in the countryside.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 별 can also mean 'star' as in celebrity (별 같은 사람). 별똥별 = shooting star.

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A sudden rain shower came.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Brief, often heavy rain; also the title of a famous Korean short story

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The sound of thunder is scary.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 천둥이 치다 = thunder strikes; often paired with 번개

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Lightning flashed.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 번개가 치다 = lightning strikes; 번쩍 = flash (onomatopoeia)

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The car got damaged because hail fell.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: Frozen precipitation; can cause significant damage

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The drought is severe this year.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 가물다 = to be dry; 가뭄이 들다 = a drought sets in

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Frost settled in the morning.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 서리가 내리다 = frost falls; appears in late autumn and early winter

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Dew has formed on the grass blades.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 이슬이 맺히다 = dew forms; 이슬비 = drizzle (dew-rain)

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The heat wave is intense this summer.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 무 (intensifier) + 더위 (heat); 폭염 is the formal/news term

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example: 한파가 와서 영하 이십 도까지 내려갔어요.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: A cold wave came and it dropped to minus twenty degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 한 = cold + 파 = wave; often used in winter weather reports

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The yellow dust was bad so I wore a mask.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 황 = yellow + 사 = sand; blows in from Chinese/Mongolian deserts in spring

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The wind chill temperature is minus ten degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 체감 = perceived + 온도 = temperature; important in Korean winters

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Today's high temperature is thirty-five degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 최고 = highest + 기온 = air temperature; used in weather forecasts

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Tomorrow's low temperature is minus five degrees.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 최저 = lowest + 기온 = air temperature; usually at dawn

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: The temperature dropped suddenly.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 기 = air + 온 = warmth; Korea uses Celsius (섭씨)

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: In winter it drops below zero.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 영 = zero + 하 = below; 영하 십 도 = minus 10 degrees

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: During the day it goes up to five degrees above zero.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 영 = zero + 상 = above; opposite of 영하

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: I went to the beach to see the sunrise.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일 = sun + 출 = come out; 일출 명소 = famous sunrise spot

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Sunset time is getting earlier.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 일 = sun + 몰 = sink; 일몰 후 = after sunset

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: Let's rest in the shade.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 나무 그늘 = tree shade; 그늘이 지다 = shade falls

날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).example_en: It's warm if you sit in the sunny spot.
날씨 & 계절 (Weather & Seasons).notes: 양 = sun + 지 = land; opposite: 음지 (shady spot)

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My head hurt so I took medicine.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 머리 means both 'head' and 'hair.' 머리를 감다 = to wash one's hair.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wash my face in the morning.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 얼굴이 작다 (small face) is a compliment in Korea.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My eyes are tired so I want to rest a bit.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Same spelling as 'snow.' 눈물 = tears (eye + water). 눈이 크다 = to have big eyes (a compliment).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I caught a cold and my nose is stuffed.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 코를 풀다 = to blow one's nose. 코피 = nosebleed.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Please open your mouth wide.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 입맛 = appetite. 입이 짧다 = to be a picky eater (mouth is short).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 음악을 너무 크게 들으면 귀가 아파요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you listen to music too loud, your ears hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 귀걸이 = earring. 귀가 밝다 = to have sharp hearing.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I brush my teeth three times a day.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 이 is casual, 치아 is more formal/medical. 이를 닦다 = to brush teeth. 사랑니 = wisdom tooth.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My throat hurts so I can't talk.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 목이 마르다 = to be thirsty (throat is dry). 목도리 = scarf.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you use the computer for a long time, your shoulders hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 어깨가 뻣뻣하다 = shoulders are stiff. Office workers often complain about 어깨 통증 (shoulder pain).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I exercised a lot so my arms hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 팔꿈치 = elbow. 팔짱을 끼다 = to fold one's arms.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wash my hands before eating.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 손님 = guest (hand + person). 손잡이 = handle.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I cut my finger while cooking.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 엄지손가락 = thumb, 검지 = index finger, 약지 = ring finger, 새끼손가락 = pinky.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: When I exercise, my chest pounds.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 가슴이 아프다 can mean physical chest pain or emotional heartache.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm hungry. Let's go eat!
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 배 also means 'boat/ship' and 'pear.' 배가 고프다 = to be hungry, 배가 부르다 = to be full.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you sit for a long time, your back hurts.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 등 also means 'etc.' in writing. 등산 = mountain climbing (climbing one's back).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I hurt my lower back lifting something heavy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 허리 통증 (lower back pain) is extremely common. 허리띠 = belt.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I walked a lot so my legs hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 다리 also means 'bridge.' 다리를 꼬다 = to cross one's legs.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The new shoes are small so my feet hurt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 발가락 = toe. 발목 = ankle. Koreans remove shoes indoors.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I fell and hurt my knee.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 무릎을 꿇다 = to kneel. Knee pain is common among hikers (등산하는 사람).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).english: to hurt; to be sick/in pain
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Where does it hurt?
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Very versatile: 배가 아프다 (stomach hurts), 마음이 아프다 (heart aches). 아파요 is the 해요체 form.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I caught a cold so I'm resting at home.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 감기에 걸리다 = to catch a cold. 독감 = influenza (more severe).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I had a fever so I couldn't go to school.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 열이 나다 = to have a fever. 체온 = body temperature. 38도 이상 = over 38 degrees (fever).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My cough won't stop.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 기침을 하다 = to cough. 기침약 = cough medicine.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My headache was bad so I took medicine.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 두 = head (한자 頭), 통 = pain (한자 痛). 두통약 = headache medicine.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I ate spoiled food and got a stomachache.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 배탈이 나다 = to get a stomachache. 체하다 = to have indigestion.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Please take the medicine after eating.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 약을 먹다 = to take medicine (literally 'eat'). 약을 바르다 = to apply medicine (ointment).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I bought cold medicine at the pharmacy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: In Korea, pharmacies are everywhere. You can get many medicines without a prescription.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I was sick so I went to the hospital.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Koreans say 병원 for any clinic or hospital. 대학병원 = university hospital (large hospital).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The doctor prescribed medicine for me.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 의사 선생님 is the polite way to address a doctor. 의사 alone is used when referring to the profession.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: The nurse gave me a shot.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 간호 = nursing/care. 간호사 is gender-neutral in Korean.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm relieved the surgery went well.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 수술을 받다 = to have/undergo surgery. 수술실 = operating room.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm scared of shots.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 주사를 맞다 = to get a shot. 주사를 놓다 = to give a shot. 예방주사 = vaccine shot.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm going to the hospital for a health checkup.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 건강검진 = health checkup (formal). 혈액 검사 = blood test. 검사 also means 'prosecutor' in legal context.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I have a cat allergy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: Loanword from English 'allergy.' 꽃가루 알레르기 = pollen allergy.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I exercise every day for my health.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 운동 = exercise/sport (noun). 헬스장 = gym. 운동을 하다 and 운동하다 are both correct.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: Our grandmother is very healthy.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 건강 = health (noun). 건강하게 지내세요 = Stay healthy (common farewell).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I worked a lot today so I'm tired.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 피곤 = fatigue (noun). 너무 피곤해요 is one of the most common Korean complaints.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I couldn't sleep last night.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 잠을 자다 = to sleep, 잠이 오다 = to feel sleepy, 잠이 안 오다 = can't fall asleep.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I usually sleep at 11 PM.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 낮잠을 자다 = to take a nap. 주무시다 is the honorific form (for elders).

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).english: to wake up; to get up
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I wake up at 7 in the morning.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 일어나다 also means 'to stand up' or 'to happen/occur.' 일어나세요! = Wake up! / Stand up!

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 혈압이 높으면 소금을 적게 먹어야 해요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If your blood pressure is high, you should eat less salt.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 血壓 meaning 'blood pressure.' 고혈압 (high blood pressure), 저혈압 (low blood pressure). 혈압을 재다 means 'to measure blood pressure.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 당뇨가 있으면 단 음식을 조심해야 해요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you have diabetes, you need to be careful with sweet foods.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 糖尿 meaning 'sugar urine.' Full term is 당뇨병 (diabetes disease). Very common health concern in Korea. 당뇨 관리 means 'diabetes management.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 이 병은 치료가 가능해요. 걱정하지 마세요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: This illness is treatable. Don't worry.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 治療 meaning 'to govern and heal.' 치료하다 means 'to treat/cure,' 치료를 받다 means 'to receive treatment.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I got a prescription from the doctor.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 處方箋 meaning 'treatment formula paper.' In Korea, you get a 처방전 from the doctor and take it to a 약국 (pharmacy) to get your medicine.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 어떤 증상이 있어요? 자세히 말해 주세요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: What symptoms do you have? Please tell me in detail.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 症狀 meaning 'disease condition.' Used at the doctor's office. Common question: 증상이 언제부터 시작됐어요? (When did the symptoms start?)

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: My body temperature is 38 degrees. I have a fever.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 體溫 meaning 'body warmth.' Normal is about 36.5°C. 체온을 재다 means 'to take one's temperature.' 체온계 is a thermometer.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 밥을 너무 빨리 먹으면 소화가 안 돼요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you eat too fast, you can't digest well.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 消化 meaning 'dissolve and transform.' 소화가 잘 되다 (to digest well), 소화가 안 되다 (indigestion). 소화제 means 'digestive medicine.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If your immunity is weak, you easily catch colds.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 免疫 meaning 'exempt from disease.' 면역력 (immune strength), 면역 체계 (immune system). Health-conscious Koreans focus on boosting 면역력.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example: 요즘 스트레스를 많이 받아요. 쉬고 싶어요.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm very stressed lately. I want to rest.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: From English 'stress.' 스트레스를 받다 (to receive/feel stress), 스트레스를 풀다 (to relieve stress). A very commonly used word in Korean daily life.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I take vitamins every day. They're good for health.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: From English 'vitamin.' Koreans are enthusiastic about supplements. 비타민C, 비타민D are commonly discussed. 종합비타민 means 'multivitamin.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I'm on a diet, so I eat less for dinner.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: In Korean, 다이어트 specifically means 'losing weight' or 'being on a diet,' not just general eating habits. 다이어트하다 means 'to diet.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I gained weight. I need to start exercising.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 體重 meaning 'body weight.' 체중이 늘다 (to gain weight), 체중이 줄다 (to lose weight). 체중계 means 'scale.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: How tall are you? I'm 170cm.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 키가 크다 (to be tall), 키가 작다 (to be short). Koreans measure height in centimeters. 키가 몇이에요? is a common question.

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: If you have good stamina, you don't get tired.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 體力 meaning 'body strength.' 체력이 좋다/나쁘다 (to have good/bad stamina). 체력을 키우다 means 'to build up stamina.'

몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).example_en: I get a health checkup every year. It's important.
몸 & 건강 (Body & Health).notes: 건강 (health) + 검진 (examination). In Korea, companies are required to provide annual 건강검진 for employees. 종합건강검진 is a comprehensive checkup.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I take the bus to school every day.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 시내버스 = city bus, 고속버스 = express bus, 마을버스 = village/local bus.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: In Seoul, the subway is the most convenient.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Seoul's subway system is excellent. Lines are numbered and color-coded. Also called 전철.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I was late so I took a taxi.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 모범택시 = deluxe taxi (black, more expensive). 콜택시 = call taxi (reserved by phone/app).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: It takes two hours to arrive by airplane.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 비행 = flight. 비행기를 타다 = to take a plane. 비행기표 = plane ticket.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I want to go to Busan by train.
교통 (Transportation).notes: KTX is Korea's high-speed train. 기차역 = train station. 무궁화호 = regular train.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I went to Jeju Island by boat.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 배 has multiple meanings: boat, stomach, pear. 여객선 = passenger ship, 유람선 = cruise ship.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I ride a bicycle in the park.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 따릉이 is Seoul's public bike-sharing system. 자전거 도로 = bike lane.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I want to buy a new car.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자동차 is formal; 차 is casual and much more common in conversation. 차 also means 'tea.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: There are really many delivery motorcycles.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'auto-bike.' Very common for 배달 (delivery) in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example: 여기서 몇 번 버스를 타야 해요?
교통 (Transportation).example_en: What number bus should I take here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 타다 is used for all vehicles. It also means 'to burn' in a different context.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I get off at the next stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 내리다 also means 'to come down' (rain, snow). 비가 내리다 = rain falls.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Transfer from Line 2 to Line 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 갈다 (to change) + 타다 (to ride). 환승 is the formal noun for 'transfer.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I booked the ticket in advance.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 승차권 is more formal for transport tickets. 표를 끊다 = to buy a ticket (older expression).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How much is the bus fare?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 기본요금 = base fare. 추가요금 = additional charge.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I need to charge money on my transit card.
교통 (Transportation).notes: T-money is the most common transit card brand in Korea. 충전하다 = to recharge.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Drive carefully!
교통 (Transportation).notes: 운전면허 = driver's license. 운전면허증 = physical license card.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I like driving.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 음주운전 = drunk driving (very serious in Korea). 초보운전 = beginner driver.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Can I park here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 주차금지 = no parking. 주차비 = parking fee.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The parking lot is full.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 지하주차장 = underground parking. 주차장 is often abbreviated as P on signs.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: What time do you arrive at the airport?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 도착 = arrival (noun). Opposite of 출발하다 (to depart).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The airplane departs at 3 PM.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 출발 = departure (noun). 출발 시간 = departure time.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please come out through Exit 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Subway exits are numbered. Giving directions with exit numbers is very common in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Where is the entrance?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 입 = enter, 구 = opening. Opposite of 출구 (exit). 정문 = main entrance/gate.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I'll get off at the next stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 버스 정류장 = bus stop. For subway, use 역 (station) instead.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Let's meet at Seoul Station.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 역 is specifically for rail stations. 지하철역 = subway station, 기차역 = train station.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How long does it take to get to Incheon Airport?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 인천국제공항 = Incheon International Airport, Korea's main international airport. 김포공항 = domestic flights.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Did you check the bus schedule?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 시간 = time, 표 = table/chart. 수업 시간표 = class schedule.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Just go straight along this road.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 길을 잃다 = to get lost. 길을 묻다 = to ask for directions. Very common word.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Traffic in Seoul is complicated.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 교통체증 = traffic jam. 대중교통 = public transportation.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: If the traffic light is red, you have to stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 신호 = signal, 등 = light. 초록불 = green light, 빨간불 = red light.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: During holidays, the highway is really congested.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 高速道路 meaning 'high-speed road.' 고속도로 휴게소 (highway rest area) is famous for its food, especially 호두과자 (walnut pastry).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I passed through the toll gate with Hi-Pass.
교통 (Transportation).notes: From English 'toll gate.' 하이패스 (Hi-Pass) is Korea's electronic toll collection system. 통행료 means 'toll fee.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Pedestrians can cross first.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 步行者 meaning 'walking person.' 보행자 우선 means 'pedestrians first.' 보행자 도로 means 'pedestrian road.'

교통 (Transportation).example: 여기서는 속도를 줄여야 해요. 학교 앞이에요.
교통 (Transportation).example_en: You need to reduce speed here. It's in front of a school.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 速度 meaning 'speed degree.' 속도 제한 (speed limit), 속도위반 (speeding violation), 과속 (speeding). 제한속도 means 'speed limit.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: There was a traffic accident, so the road is blocked.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 事故 meaning 'incident.' 교통사고 (traffic accident), 사고가 나다 (an accident occurs). 사고 조심하세요 means 'be careful of accidents.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: During rush hour, the traffic congestion is severe.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 交通滞症 meaning 'traffic stagnation.' Also commonly called 교통 정체. 길이 막히다 is the casual way to say 'the road is jammed.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please turn on the GPS. I don't know the way.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Often shortened to 내비. 내비 켜다 (to turn on GPS). Popular navigation apps in Korea include 카카오맵 and 네이버 지도.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: When you get in the car, always put on your seatbelt.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 안전 (safety) + 벨트 (belt). 안전벨트를 매다/하다 means 'to put on a seatbelt.' Required by law for all passengers in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: To get a driver's license, you have to take a test.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 免許證 meaning 'permit certificate.' 운전면허증 is the full term. 면허를 따다 means 'to get a license.' 국제면허증 means 'international driver's license.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: A rental car is convenient on Jeju Island.
교통 (Transportation).notes: From English 'rent-a-car.' Also written as 렌트카. Very popular for Jeju Island trips since public transport there is limited.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Public transportation in Seoul is very convenient.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 大衆交通 meaning 'mass transportation.' Includes 버스, 지하철, 기차. Seoul has one of the best 대중교통 systems in the world.

교통 (Transportation).example: 첫차가 몇 시에 있어요? 일찍 가야 해요.
교통 (Transportation).example_en: What time is the first train? I need to go early.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 첫 (first) + 차 (vehicle). Usually around 5:00-5:30 AM for subways in Seoul. Opposite of 막차 (last train/bus).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I missed the last train. I have to take a taxi.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 막 (last) + 차 (vehicle). Usually around midnight for Seoul subways. Missing 막차 is a common experience, leading to late-night taxi rides.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: You need to transfer from Line 2 to Line 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 換乘 meaning 'change ride.' 환승하다 means 'to transfer.' Free transfers between bus and subway are available within 30 minutes using a 교통카드.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The road was gridlocked, so it took a whole hour.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 停滯 meaning 'stagnation.' 교통 정체 (traffic gridlock). Slightly more formal than 길이 막히다 but widely used in news and conversation.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please move to the right lane.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 차 (car) + 선 (line). 1차선, 2차선 = lane 1, lane 2. 차선 변경 = lane change.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: If you speed, you have to pay a fine.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 과 (excessive) + 속 (speed). 과속 카메라 = speed camera. 과속하다 = to speed.

교통 (Transportation).english: running a red light; traffic signal violation
교통 (Transportation).example_en: I got a ticket for running a red light.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 신호 (signal) + 위반 (violation). 딱지 = traffic ticket (colloquial). Very serious offense in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How much is the parking violation fine?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 벌 (penalty) + 금 (money). 벌금을 내다 = to pay a fine. 벌금을 물다 = to be fined.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: You should absolutely never drink and drive.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 음주 (drinking alcohol) + 운전 (driving). Severe penalties in Korea. 대리운전 = designated driver service.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I need to renew my car insurance.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자동차 보험 = car insurance. 보험료 = insurance premium. 보험에 들다 = to get insurance.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I'm going to get a car wash this weekend.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 세 (wash) + 차 (car). 세차하다 = to wash a car. 자동 세차 = automatic car wash.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please check the tire pressure.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English. 타이어를 갈다 = to change tires. 스노 타이어 = snow tires.

교통 (Transportation).example: 기름이 거의 없어요, 주유소에 가야 해요.
교통 (Transportation).example_en: We're almost out of gas, we need to go to a gas station.
교통 (Transportation).notes: In driving context, means fuel/gasoline. 기름값 = gas price. 기름을 넣다 = to fill up gas.

교통 (Transportation).english: to refuel; to fill up gas
교통 (Transportation).example_en: Can I refuel here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 주유 (refueling). 주유소 = gas station. 셀프 주유 = self-service gas station.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: This car needs diesel.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Also called 디젤. At gas stations: 휘발유 (gasoline), 경유 (diesel), LPG. Be careful not to put the wrong fuel!

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Where is the electric car charging station?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 전기 (electricity) + 차 (car). 충전소 = charging station. 전기차 보조금 = EV subsidy.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Self-driving technology is advancing rapidly.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자율 (autonomous) + 주행 (driving). 자율주행차 = self-driving car. A hot topic in Korean tech news.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please enter the address into the GPS.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Short for 내비게이션. Koreans almost always use the shortened form 내비 in speech.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Let's check the dashcam footage.
교통 (Transportation).notes: In Korean, 블랙박스 means dashcam (not airplane black box). Almost every car in Korea has one.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What is your hobby?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: One of the most common self-introduction questions in Korean. 취미 생활 = hobby life/leisure activities.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Do you want to go see a movie this weekend?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 영화관 = movie theater. 영화를 보다 = to watch a movie. Korean cinema is world-renowned.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I like listening to music.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 음악을 듣다 = to listen to music. K-pop = 케이팝. 클래식 음악 = classical music.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This song is really good!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래를 부르다 = to sing a song. 노래방 = karaoke room.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to learn to dance.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 춤 = dance (noun). 춤을 추다 is the separated form. K-pop 댄스 is very popular.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What kind of exercise/sport do you like?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 운동 covers both exercise and sports. 운동선수 = athlete. 운동화 = sneakers.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play soccer with friends.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 축구를 하다 = to play soccer. Korea's national team is very popular. 월드컵 = World Cup.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Shall we go watch a baseball game?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 야구 is extremely popular in Korea. 프로야구 = professional baseball. 야구장 = baseball stadium.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I often play basketball at school.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 농구를 하다 = to play basketball. 농구 코트 = basketball court.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go to the sea to swim in summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 수영장 = swimming pool. 수영을 하다 = to swim. 수영복 = swimsuit.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I run every morning.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 달리다 = to run (verb). 마라톤 = marathon. 조깅 = jogging.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going hiking this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 등산 is a hugely popular hobby in Korea. 등산복 = hiking clothes. 등산화 = hiking boots.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I do yoga to relieve stress.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 요가 학원 = yoga studio/class. 명상 = meditation, often paired with yoga.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going on a trip to Japan next month.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 여행을 가다 = to go on a trip. 해외여행 = overseas travel. 국내여행 = domestic travel.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Could you take a photo for me?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 사진을 찍다 = to take a photo. 셀카 = selfie (from 'self camera').

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to learn Korean cooking.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 요리하다 = to cook. 요리사 = chef. 집에서 요리해 먹다 = to cook and eat at home.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My younger sibling draws well.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 그림을 그리다 = to draw a picture. 그림책 = picture book.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play online games with friends.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: PC방 = internet/gaming cafe. Korea has a major esports (e스포츠) culture.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I take a walk in the park in the evening.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 산책하다 = to take a walk. 산책을 하다 also works. 반려동물과 산책 = walking with a pet.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Reading is the best hobby.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 독서하다 = to read (books). More formal than 책을 읽다 (to read a book).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I went shopping in Myeongdong.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 온라인 쇼핑 = online shopping. 쇼핑몰 = shopping mall. 쿠팡 = Korea's major e-commerce site.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My father likes fishing.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 낚시를 하다 = to go fishing. 낚싯대 = fishing rod. 바다낚시 = sea fishing.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going camping this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 캠핑장 = campsite/campground. 글램핑 = glamping (glamorous camping), very popular in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: After the work dinner, we go to karaoke.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래 = song + 방 = room. A quintessential Korean social activity. 코인노래방 = coin karaoke (cheaper, by song).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Are there any interesting dramas these days?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 한국 드라마 = Korean drama (K-drama). 넷플릭스 = Netflix. 드라마를 보다 = to watch a drama.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I watch TV in the evening.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: In conversation, Koreans usually say TV (티비). 텔레비전 is the full word but rarely used in casual speech.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: The internet in Korea is really fast.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Korea has some of the fastest internet in the world. 와이파이 = Wi-Fi.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What is your cell phone number?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Also called 휴대폰 (more formal) or 스마트폰 (smartphone). 핸드폰 is most common in casual speech.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This book is really interesting.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 책을 읽다 = to read a book. 책방/서점 = bookstore. 도서관 = library.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 신문을 읽다 = to read a newspaper. 뉴스 = news. Print newspapers are declining in Korea too.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to a concert next week!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: K-pop 콘서트 tickets are very hard to get. 공연 is the native Korean word for 'performance.'

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to see a musical performance.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 공연장 = performance venue. Covers theater, musicals, concerts, and other live shows.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Let's go to the art exhibition together.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 전시 = exhibition/display. 전시회를 보다 / 전시를 보다 = to see an exhibition.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Have you been to the National Museum?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 국립중앙박물관 = National Museum of Korea (in Seoul). 박물관 입장료 = museum admission fee.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This art gallery has many famous paintings.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 미술 = art/fine arts. 미술관 vs 갤러리 - both are used. 현대미술관 = contemporary art museum.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I learned piano when I was young.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 피아노를 치다 = to play piano (치다 = to hit/strike). 피아노 학원 = piano academy.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm learning to play guitar.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 기타를 치다 = to play guitar. Note: 기타 also means 'other/etc.' in different contexts.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I always sing when I shower.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래를 부르다 is more common than 노래하다 in natural speech. Both are correct.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I like drawing landscapes.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 그림을 그리다 = to draw a picture. 그리다 also means 'to miss someone' (그리워하다).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I take lots of photos when I travel.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 사진을 찍다 = to take a photo. 찍다 also means 'to stamp' or 'to dip (in sauce).'

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example: 주말에 친구들이랑 볼링 치러 갈 거예요.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to go bowling with friends this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'bowling.' 볼링을 치다 means 'to bowl.' 볼링장 means 'bowling alley.' A popular group activity in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: In winter, we go to Gangwon-do to ski.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'ski.' 스키를 타다 means 'to ski.' 스키장 means 'ski resort.' Popular Korean ski resorts include 용평, 하이원, 비발디파크.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: In winter, I ice skate at the ice rink.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'skate.' 스케이트를 타다 means 'to skate.' 아이스링크 means 'ice rink.' Seoul Plaza has a famous outdoor rink in winter.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Surfing in Yangyang is popular these days.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'surfing.' 서핑하다 means 'to surf.' 양양 in Gangwon-do has become Korea's surfing hotspot.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go to the gym and work out every day.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'health.' In Korean, 헬스 specifically means 'going to the gym/weight training.' 헬스장 means 'gym/fitness center.' 헬스하다 means 'to work out.'

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I started pilates. My posture has improved.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Very popular in Korea, especially among women. 필라테스 학원 (pilates studio) can be found in almost every Korean neighborhood.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I made a scarf by knitting in winter.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 뜨개질하다 means 'to knit.' A relaxing hobby. 코바늘 뜨개질 is crochet, 대바늘 뜨개질 is needle knitting.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example: 원예를 시작했어요. 꽃을 키우는 게 재미있어요.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I started gardening. Growing flowers is fun.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 園藝 meaning 'garden art.' 원예 활동 (gardening activity). 식물 키우기 (growing plants) is a related popular hobby. 플랜테리어 (plant + interior) is a Korean trend.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: On rainy days, we play board games.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'board game.' 보드게임 카페 (board game cafe) is popular in Korea, where you can rent and play various games.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I completed a 1000-piece puzzle!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'puzzle.' 퍼즐을 맞추다 means 'to put together a puzzle.' Completed puzzles are often framed as art in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I follow along while watching cooking YouTube.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 유튜버 means 'YouTuber.' YouTube is hugely popular in Korea. 먹방 (eating shows) and 브이로그 (vlogs) are popular Korean YouTube genres.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I listen to podcasts during my commute.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: From English 'podcast.' 팟캐스트를 듣다 means 'to listen to a podcast.' Korean podcast platforms include 팟빵 and Apple Podcasts.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I read webtoons during lunchtime. They're fun.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: A Korean innovation: digital comics designed for vertical scrolling on phones. 네이버 웹툰 and 카카오 웹툰 are the biggest platforms. Many Korean dramas are based on webtoons.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I read a lot of comics when I was young.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 만화책 means 'comic book.' 만화방 (manhwa cafe) is a place to read comics. 만화 영화 is an older term for animated movies.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I volunteer every weekend. It's rewarding.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 自願奉仕 meaning 'willing service.' 자원봉사하다 means 'to volunteer.' 자원봉사자 means 'volunteer.' Required for Korean students as part of their school record.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play badminton with friends every weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 배드민턴을 치다 = to play badminton. Very popular recreational sport in Korea, played in parks.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play table tennis at the office during lunch.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 탁구를 치다 = to play table tennis. 탁구대 = ping pong table. Popular in Korean workplaces.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I recently started learning golf.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 골프를 치다 = to play golf. 골프장 = golf course. Very popular in Korean business culture.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play tennis twice a week.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 테니스를 치다 = to play tennis. 테니스장 = tennis court. Growing in popularity in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to try running a marathon next year.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 마라톤을 뛰다 = to run a marathon. 서울 마라톤 is a major annual event.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I tried riding a yacht in Jeju.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 요트를 타다 = to ride a yacht. 요트 투어 = yacht tour. Popular in coastal areas like Busan and Jeju.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to get my diving certification this summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 스쿠버 다이빙 = scuba diving. 자격증을 따다 = to get a certification. Popular in Jeju.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I can't do bungee jumping because it's scary.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 번지점프를 하다 = to bungee jump. Famous spots in Korea include 가평 and 인제.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go rafting with friends in the summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 래프팅을 하다 = to go rafting. 동강 and 한탄강 are popular rafting spots in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Riding the zipline was such a thrill!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 짚라인을 타다 = to ride a zipline. 짜릿하다 = thrilling. Found at adventure parks across Korea.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm really happy because I passed the exam.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 기쁘다 is for a specific reason or event. Conjugates irregularly: 기쁘 → 기뻐요 (ㅡ drops).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm happy when I'm with my family.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 행복하다 is a deeper, more lasting happiness than 기쁘다. From 한자 幸福.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This movie is so sad.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 슬프 → 슬퍼요. Often used with 너무 for emphasis.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 친구가 약속을 안 지켜서 화가 나요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm angry because my friend didn't keep the promise.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 화가 나다 (with subject marker 가) is the full form. 화내다 means 'to get angry at someone.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: It's scary to walk alone at night.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 무섭 → 무서워요. Can mean 'I'm scared' or 'it's scary' depending on context.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was surprised because there was a sudden loud sound.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Past tense 놀랐어요 is very common. 깜짝 놀라다 means 'to be startled.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I sometimes feel lonely because I live alone.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 외롭 → 외로워요. 외로움 is the noun form meaning 'loneliness.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm bored because I have nothing to do.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Very casual/everyday word. 지루하다 is a more formal way to say 'boring.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm worried because I have an interview tomorrow.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 걱정하다 = to worry (active); 걱정되다 = to be worried (passive/involuntary feeling).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I always get nervous before presentations.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 긴장하다 = to be tense (active); 긴장되다 = to feel nervous (involuntary). From 한자 緊張.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel embarrassed singing in front of people.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 부끄럽 → 부끄러워요. Can mean both 'shy' and 'embarrassed.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm proud because my son studies hard.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 자랑스럽 → 자랑스러워요. 자랑하다 means 'to brag/boast.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was touched after hearing that story.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 감동받다 (to receive being moved) is also very common. From 한자 感動.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was a bit disappointed after seeing the results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 失望. Often softened with 좀 (a bit) in conversation.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm tired because I worked a lot today.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 疲困. Very high-frequency word in daily life.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm hungry because I didn't eat breakfast.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 배고프 → 배고파요. Literally 'stomach is empty.' 배 = stomach.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm full because I ate too much.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 배부르 → 배불러요. Opposite of 배고프다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm thirsty after exercising.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 목마르 → 목말라요. Literally 'throat is dry.' 목 = throat/neck.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm sleepy because I couldn't sleep last night.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 졸리다 = to feel sleepy; 졸다 = to doze off. Don't confuse the two.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I have a headache. (My head hurts.)
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅡ irregular: 아프 → 아파요. Used for all kinds of pain: 배가 아프다, 다리가 아프다, etc.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The weather is nice today.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 좋다 = something is good; 좋아하다 = to like (active verb). Both are essential.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I dislike spicy food.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 싫다 = to dislike (adjective); 싫어하다 = to dislike (active verb). Opposite of 좋다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This drama is really fun/interesting.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Literally 'interest exists.' 재미 = fun/interest + 있다 = to exist.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: That movie was boring.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Literally 'interest doesn't exist.' 재미 + 없다. Opposite of 재미있다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm excited because I'm going on a trip tomorrow!
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Casual and energetic feeling. 신나는 음악 = exciting/upbeat music.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm frustrated because we can't communicate.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Can mean physically stuffy (in a room) or emotionally frustrated. Very common in Korean.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This sofa is really comfortable.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Used for both physical comfort and feeling at ease. 편안하다 is a more formal synonym.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This chair is very uncomfortable.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 불 (不) + 편하다. Used for physical discomfort or inconvenient situations.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm satisfied with this result.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 滿足. Opposite: 불만족하다 (dissatisfied).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 그때 더 열심히 공부할 걸 후회해요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I regret not studying harder back then.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: From 한자 後悔. Often used with -(으)ㄹ 걸 (I should have...).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I miss my hometown.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: ㅂ irregular: 그립 → 그리워요. Used for people, places, or times you long for.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm upset because my friend said something mean to me.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 속 = inside/heart + 상하다 = to go bad. Literally 'the inside is hurt.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel wronged because I got scolded even though I didn't do it.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A uniquely Korean emotion — feeling unfairly blamed or treated. No perfect English equivalent.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm excited because it's my first date.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A fluttery, anticipatory excitement, often romantic. 설렘 is the noun form.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel proud and fulfilled after finishing the project.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A warm sense of accomplishment. More personal than 자랑스럽다 which can be about others.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be annoyed / to be irritated
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The bus isn't coming, so I'm annoyed.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Very commonly used to express irritation. 짜증 is the noun (irritation). 짜증을 내다 means 'to express annoyance (at someone).'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be flustered / to be embarrassed
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was flustered because I was suddenly asked a question.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Describes the feeling of being caught off guard. 당황스럽다 is an adjective form meaning 'flustering/embarrassing.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel hurt / to feel let down / disappointed
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel hurt because my friend canceled our plans.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A uniquely Korean emotion: a gentle hurt or disappointment from someone close, not anger but sadness. Hard to translate perfectly into English.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel relieved / to be at ease
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was relieved because the test results were good.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 安心 meaning 'peaceful heart.' 안심이 되다 also means 'to feel relieved.' Opposite of 걱정되다 (to be worried).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be bored / to be tedious
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 이 영화 너무 지루해요. 다른 거 볼까요?
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This movie is so boring. Shall we watch something else?
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Describes boredom from something tedious, not from having nothing to do (that would be 심심하다). 지루한 수업 means 'a boring class.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel refreshed / to be fresh
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The morning air is refreshing. I feel good.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 爽快 meaning 'fresh and pleasant.' Used for both physical and mental refreshment. 상쾌한 아침 means 'a refreshing morning.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be depressed / to feel gloomy
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: When it rains, I get gloomy.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 憂鬱 meaning 'anxious and depressed.' Can describe temporary sadness or clinical depression. 우울증 means 'depression (clinical).'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be excited / to be worked up
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The concert is tomorrow, so I'm so excited!
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 興奮 meaning 'excitement.' Can be positive (excited) or negative (agitated). 흥분하지 마세요 means 'please calm down.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be jealous / to feel jealousy
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I get jealous when my boyfriend talks to other girls.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 嫉妬 meaning 'jealousy.' 질투심 means 'feelings of jealousy.' 질투가 나다 also means 'to feel jealous.' Can be romantic or general envy.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be grateful / to be thankful
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm really grateful that you helped me.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 感謝 meaning 'feel thanks.' More heartfelt than just 고맙다. 감사합니다 is the formal polite form, the most common way to say thank you in formal settings.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be absurd / to be bewildered / ridiculous
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 그 사람이 한 말이 너무 황당해요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: What that person said is so absurd.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Describes the feeling when something is so ridiculous or unexpected that you don't know how to react. 황당한 상황 means 'an absurd situation.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel empty / to feel something is missing
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Now that my friend has left, my heart feels empty.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A distinctly Korean feeling of emptiness or something missing. Can be emotional (missing someone) or physical (still hungry after eating). 허전한 마음 means 'an empty feeling.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel reassured / to feel full and satisfied
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I ate a lot, so I feel full and satisfied.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Has two meanings: physically full/satisfied after eating, and emotionally reassured or secure. 든든한 사람 means 'a dependable person.' 든든한 한 끼 means 'a filling meal.'

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to bluff / to exaggerate / to lie (slang)
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Don't bluff! Tell me the truth.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Casual/slang word for exaggerating or lying. 뻥 means 'a fib/bluff.' 뻥이야! means 'That's a lie!' Very colloquial and used among friends.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I had a mental meltdown when I saw the test results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Slang abbreviation of 멘탈 붕괴 (mental collapse). Very popular slang. 멘붕이 오다 means 'to have a mental breakdown.' Used casually and humorously, not for serious clinical situations.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: You can speak confidently.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Implies being unapologetically confident. 당당히 = confidently (adverb). Different from 자신감 있다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was doubtful at first, but it was true.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 의심 = suspicion/doubt. 의심이 가다 = to become suspicious. Can be directed at people or facts.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I really respect my parents.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 존경 = respect/admiration. Stronger than 존중하다 (to respect/value). 존경하는 선생님 = respected teacher.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Don't ignore what I'm saying.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 무시 = disregard/contempt. Can imply looking down on someone. 무시당하다 = to be ignored/disrespected.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I don't want to receive pity.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 동정 = pity/sympathy. Can have a negative nuance (unwanted pity). 동정심 = feeling of pity.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be sick of; to be fed up
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm sick of it because it's the same menu every day.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Very colloquial and commonly used. 질리도록 = until you're sick of it. 물리다 is a synonym.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I've gotten used to life in Korea now.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 익숙해지다 = to become familiar. Opposite of 낯설다. -에 익숙하다 = to be used to something.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 처음 가는 곳이라 모든 게 낯설어요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Everything feels unfamiliar because it's my first time here.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 낯 = face/appearance. Opposite of 익숙하다. 낯선 사람 = stranger.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I fell in front of people and it was embarrassing.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Similar to 부끄럽다 but more about social awkwardness. Used when you feel exposed or caught off guard.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel deflated because the exam was cancelled.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A feeling of emptiness after anticipation. Like when you prepared a lot but it was all for nothing.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm anxious while waiting for the results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Implies nervous restlessness. Stronger than 긴장되다. 초조하게 기다리다 = to wait anxiously.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Hearing that news, I really feel sorry about it.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Expresses sympathetic sadness for someone else's misfortune. Very commonly used. 안타깝게도 = unfortunately.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The answer is a bit vague.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Very commonly used in daily Korean. 애매한 상황 = ambiguous situation. 애매모호하다 = even more vague.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This problem is too complicated.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Can describe both abstract complexity and physical crowdedness. 머리가 복잡하다 = my mind is cluttered.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: It was a simpler problem than I thought.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Opposite of 복잡하다. 단순히 = simply. Can sometimes imply 'simple-minded' depending on context.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 빨갛 → 빨개요. 빨간 is the modifier form (빨간 모자 = red hat).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The sky is really blue today.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 파랗 → 파래요. 파란 is the modifier form (파란 바다 = blue sea).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The leaves turn yellow in autumn.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 노랗 → 노래요. 노란 is the modifier form (노란 꽃 = yellow flower).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: It snowed so the world is white.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅎ irregular: 하얗 → 하얘요. 하얀 is the modifier form (하얀 구름 = white cloud).
ㅎ irregular: 까맣 → 까매요. 까만 is the modifier form (까만 고양이 = black cat).
초록색 is a noun (color name). 초록색의 or 초록 is used as a modifier. No ㅎ irregular form.
주황색 is a noun. Also called 오렌지색 in casual speech.
보라색 is a noun. 보랏빛 means 'purple light/hue' and sounds more poetic.
분홍색 is a noun. Also called 핑크색 casually. 분홍 can be used alone as modifier.
From 한자 灰色. 회색빛 means 'grayish hue.'
From 한자 褐色. Sometimes 브라운 (from English 'brown') is used for fashion.
큰 is the modifier form (큰 집 = big house). Opposite: 작다.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: These clothes are too small for me.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: 작은 is the modifier form (작은 강아지 = small puppy). Opposite: 크다.
많은 is the modifier form. 많이 is the adverb form (많이 먹어요 = eat a lot).
적은 is the modifier form. Opposite: 많다. Don't confuse with 적다 (to write down).
긴 is the modifier form (긴 머리 = long hair). Opposite: 짧다.
짧은 is the modifier form. Used for length, not height. Opposite: 길다.
넓은 is the modifier form (넓은 공원 = spacious park). Opposite: 좁다.
좁은 is the modifier form. Opposite: 넓다.
높은 is the modifier form. Used for buildings, mountains, prices — not for people's height (키가 크다).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: This table is a bit low.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: 낮은 is the modifier form. Opposite: 높다. Don't confuse with 낮 (daytime, noun).
ㅂ irregular: 무겁 → 무거워요. Opposite: 가볍다.
ㅂ irregular: 가볍 → 가벼워요. Opposite: 무겁다.
ㅡ irregular: 빠르 → 빨라요. Adverb: 빨리. Opposite: 느리다.
느린 is the modifier form. Adverb: 느리게. Opposite: 빠르다.
ㅂ irregular: 새롭 → 새로워요. 새 is a shorter modifier (새 차 = new car).
오래된 is the modifier form. Only for things, not people. For people's age, use 나이가 많다.
좋은 is the modifier form (좋은 사람 = good person). One of the most used adjectives.
ㅡ irregular: 나쁘 → 나빠요. 나쁜 is the modifier form. Opposite: 좋다.
ㅡ irregular: 예쁘 → 예뻐요. Mostly used for women, children, or things. 아름답다 is more literary.
Past tense form 잘생겼어요 is the standard way to say it. Literally 'well-formed.'
ㅂ irregular: 귀엽 → 귀여워요. Used for babies, animals, small things, and idols.
깨끗한 is the modifier form. 깨끗하게 is the adverb form. Opposite: 더럽다.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: Your hands are dirty. Wash them.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: ㅂ irregular: 더럽 → 더러워요. Opposite: 깨끗하다.
밝은 is the modifier form (밝은 미래 = bright future). Opposite: 어둡다.
ㅂ irregular: 어둡 → 어두워요. Opposite: 밝다.
따뜻한 is the modifier form (따뜻한 차 = warm tea). Between 뜨겁다 and 차갑다.
ㅂ irregular: 차갑 → 차가워요. For touch/objects. For weather, use 춥다.
ㅂ irregular: 뜨겁 → 뜨거워요. For touch/objects. For weather, use 덥다.
ㅂ irregular: 부드럽 → 부드러워요. Used for texture, personality, and voice.
Onomatopoeic origin. Also used figuratively: 딱딱한 분위기 = stiff atmosphere.
ㅂ irregular: 쉽 → 쉬워요. 쉬운 is the modifier form. Opposite: 어렵다.
ㅂ irregular: 어렵 → 어려워요. Opposite: 쉽다.
From 한자 重要. 중요한 is the modifier form (중요한 약속 = important appointment).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: That road is dangerous at night.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: From 한자 危險. 위험한 is the modifier form. Opposite: 안전하다 (safe).
연한 + color name; opposite: 진하다 (dark/deep)
Used for both colors (진한 빨간색 = deep red) and flavors
Can be positive (gorgeous) or negative (too showy) depending on context
Opposite of 화려하다; carries a positive nuance of being tasteful
Used for objects and physical health; 몸이 튼튼하다 = to be physically strong
Opposite of 강하다 (strong); ~에 약하다 = weak against something
Irregular conjugation: 두껍다 → 두꺼워요; opposite: 얇다
Opposite of 두껍다; pronunciation: [얄따]

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: This cake is moist and delicious.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Positive nuance; used for skin (피부가 촉촉하다) and food texture
