색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: I like this chicken because it's crispy.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: 바삭바삭 = very crispy (doubled for emphasis); ideal texture for fried food

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: I ate a sweet strawberry cake.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: More poetic/pleasant than 달다; also used figuratively: 달콤한 말 = sweet words

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The sesame oil smells nutty and savory.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: A uniquely Korean flavor concept; no exact English equivalent
신선 = fresh/new; used for food, air, and ideas

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The milk has gone bad. Throw it away.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: 음식이 상하다 = food goes bad; also means 'to be hurt' (마음이 상하다)
Used for both ripening fruit and cooking: 고기가 다 익었어요 = the meat is cooked
날 = raw + 것 = thing; 날생선 = raw fish, 날달걀 = raw egg
적당히 (adverb) = moderately, in moderation
충분히 (adverb) = sufficiently, plenty
Opposite of 충분하다; 부족함 = shortage, lack
완 = complete + 벽 = wall (flawless); 완벽하게 = perfectly (adverb)

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: What are you doing?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: The most versatile verb in Korean. Combines with many nouns to form compound verbs: 공부하다, 운동하다, etc.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I go to school.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Takes the particle 에 for destination. Irregular in some forms: 가 + 아요 → 가요 (not 가아요).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: My friend comes to my house.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Irregular: 오 + 아요 → 와요. Opposite of 가다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Did you eat lunch?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 밥 먹었어요? (Have you eaten rice?) is a common Korean greeting meaning 'How are you?'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I drink a lot of water.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 시 + 어요 → 셔요. Used for all drinks: 커피를 마시다, 술을 마시다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I slept well last night.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 잘 자요 = Good night (literally 'sleep well'). Very common expression.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to wake up, to get up
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wake up at 7 every morning.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Also means 'to stand up' or 'to happen/occur.' Context determines the meaning.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wash my hands before eating.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 씻 has a double consonant batch (ㅆ). 샤워하다 is used for 'to shower.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: What are you going to wear today?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Only for clothes on the body. Shoes = 신다, hat = 쓰다, glasses = 쓰다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I take off my shoes when I enter the house.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for removing clothes, shoes, hats, glasses. Opposite of 입다/신다/쓰다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I go out wearing sneakers.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Only for footwear (shoes, socks, slippers). 신발 (shoes) comes from this verb.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: May I sit here?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 앉으세요 = Please sit down (polite). The ㄵ consonant cluster simplifies in pronunciation.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wait standing in line.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 일어서다 = to stand up (from sitting). 멈춰 서다 = to stop and stand.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I walk in the park.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄷ irregular: 걷 → 걸어요. Don't confuse with 걷다 (to collect/gather) which is regular.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The children are running in the playground.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Can mean both 'run' and 'jump.' 달리다 specifically means 'to run.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to see, to watch, to look
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I watch movies on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 보 + 아요 → 봐요. Very versatile: 시험을 보다 = take a test, TV를 보다 = watch TV.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I listen to music often.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄷ irregular: 듣 → 들어요. 수업을 듣다 = to take a class.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to speak, to say, to tell
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please speak slowly.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 말씀하시다 is the honorific form. 이야기하다 is 'to talk/chat.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm reading an interesting book these days.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: The ㄺ consonant cluster: pronounced [익] before consonants, [일] before vowels.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I write in my diary every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Multiple meanings: write, use, wear (hat/glasses), bitter. Context is key. ㅡ irregular: 쓰 → 써요.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I make a cake on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb: the ㄹ drops before ㄴ, ㅂ, ㅅ. 만든 = that was made (modifier).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I buy fruit at the market.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 사 + 아요 → 사요. 사 주다 = to buy for someone.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: This store sells bread.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. Opposite: 사다. 팔리다 = to be sold (passive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I give a present to my friend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 주 + 어요 → 줘요. -아/어 주다 as auxiliary means 'do for someone.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I received a birthday present.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite: 주다. 받아들이다 = to accept.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please open the window.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. Opposite: 닫다. 열리다 = to be opened (passive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please close the door.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite: 열다. 닫히다 = to be closed (passive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please turn on the light.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for lights, electronics, heaters. Opposite: 끄다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I turn off the light before sleeping.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㅡ irregular: 끄 → 꺼요. Opposite: 켜다. Also means 'to extinguish.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm looking for my wallet.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Two meanings: 'to look for' (searching) and 'to find' (success). Also: 'to withdraw money.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please wait here for a moment.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Often used with -아/어 주세요 for polite requests. 기다림 = the wait (noun).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm meeting a friend tomorrow.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 만나서 반갑습니다 = Nice to meet you (formal). 만남 = meeting/encounter (noun).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I call my mom.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 전화 = telephone. 전화를 받다 = to answer the phone. 전화를 끊다 = to hang up.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I study Korean every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 공부 (noun) + 하다. From 한자 工夫. The most common word for academic study.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I work at a company.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 일 (noun: work) + 하다. 직장에 다니다 = to go to work (attend a workplace).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to rest, to take a break
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I rest at home on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Also means 'to breathe' in compound 숨을 쉬다. 휴식 is the formal noun for 'rest.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Class starts at 9 o'clock.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 시작 (noun) + 하다. From 한자 始作. Can be transitive or intransitive.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Class ends at 12 o'clock.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 끝나다 = it ends (intransitive). 끝내다 = to finish it (transitive). 끝 = end (noun).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I arrived at the airport.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: From 한자 到着. Takes 에 particle for the destination.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The train is departing soon.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: From 한자 出發. Opposite: 도착하다. 출발 시간 = departure time.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Let's hang out together on the weekend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. For adults, it means 'to hang out/have fun,' not just children's play.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I like Korean food.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Active verb (takes 을/를). 좋다 (adjective) vs 좋아하다 (verb): 커피가 좋아요 vs 커피를 좋아해요.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I hate lies.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Active verb (takes 을/를). Stronger than 안 좋아하다. Opposite: 좋아하다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I need an umbrella.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: From 한자 必要. The needed thing takes 이/가 (subject marker), not 을/를.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Do you know that person?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. 알겠습니다 = I understand/got it. Opposite: 모르다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I don't know much about that.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㅡ irregular: 모르 → 몰라요. Opposite: 알다. 모르겠어요 = I'm not sure.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to exist, to have, to be (at a place)
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Do you have time?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: One of the most important Korean words. Location + 에 있다. Opposite: 없다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to not exist, to not have
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I don't have money.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite: 있다. 재미없다, 맛없다 show how 없다 combines with nouns.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I live in Seoul.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. 살 + ㅂ니다 → 삽니다. Takes 에서 for the place where you live.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm learning Korean.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 배우 + 어요 → 배워요. Don't confuse with 배우 (actor/actress, noun).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I teach English.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 가르치 + 어요 → 가르쳐요. Takes 에게/한테 for the person taught.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please help me.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 돕다 (to help) + 주다 (to give). 도와주세요 is the most common way to ask for help.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I borrow books from the library.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Means both 'borrow' and 'lend' — context determines which. 빌려주다 = to lend.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I lost my phone.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 잃다 (to lose) + 버리다 (completely). 버리다 adds a sense of 'completely gone.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I cry when I watch sad movies.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: ㄹ verb. 울음 = crying (noun). 울리다 = to make someone cry.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I laughed because that story was funny.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Covers both laughing and smiling. 미소 짓다 specifically means 'to smile.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I clean my room every weekend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 청소 (noun: cleaning) + 하다. From 한자 清掃. 대청소 = deep cleaning.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I need to do laundry.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 빨래 (noun: laundry) + 하다. 빨래를 널다 = to hang laundry. 빨래를 개다 = to fold laundry.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I cook at home.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 요리 (noun: cooking/dish) + 하다. From 한자 料理. 요리사 = chef.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I drive to work every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 운전 (noun: driving) + 하다. From 한자 運轉. 운전면허 = driver's license.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I go by subway.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for all transportation: 버스를 타다, 택시를 타다, 비행기를 타다. Opposite: 내리다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to get off, to go down
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I get off at the next station.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 타다 for transportation. Also means 'to fall' (비가 내리다 = rain falls).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: It takes 30 minutes from home to school.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: For time: 시간이 걸리다. For illness: 감기에 걸리다 = to catch a cold.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I changed to a new phone.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Active verb (you change something). 바뀌다 = to be changed (passive/intransitive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to fix, to repair, to correct
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I fixed the computer.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for repairing things and correcting mistakes. 고장나다 = to break down.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please throw the ball. I'll catch it.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 던지다 is the basic word for throwing. 쓰레기를 던지다 means 'to throw away trash' (but 버리다 is more proper). Can also be used figuratively: 질문을 던지다 means 'to throw/pose a question.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to catch / to grab / to hold
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I raised my hand to catch a taxi.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Very versatile: 택시를 잡다 (catch a taxi), 손을 잡다 (hold hands), 기회를 잡다 (seize an opportunity), 범인을 잡다 (catch a criminal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please push the door. It won't open.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 당기다 (to pull). Doors in Korea are often labeled 미세요 (push) and 당기세요 (pull).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: You have to pull this door to open it.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 밀다 (to push). Also used as 당기다 meaning 'to crave' in casual speech: 치킨이 당겨요 (I'm craving chicken).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to lift / to carry / to hold up
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example: 이 상자 좀 들어 주세요. 무거워요.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please lift this box for me. It's heavy.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Extremely versatile verb with many meanings depending on context: 손을 들다 (raise hand), 돈이 들다 (cost money), 마음에 들다 (to like/be pleased with), 잠이 들다 (fall asleep).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to put down / to let go / to release
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please put your bag down here.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 놓다 means to place something down or let go of it. 놓치다 means 'to miss' (a bus, chance, etc.). 내려놓다 means 'to put down / to let go emotionally.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Do you put sugar in your coffee?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 빼다 (to take out). 가방에 넣다 (put in a bag), 주머니에 넣다 (put in a pocket). 넣어 주세요 means 'please put it in.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to take out / to remove / to subtract
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example: 양파를 빼 주세요. 양파를 못 먹어요.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please leave out the onion. I can't eat onion.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 넣다 (to put in). Very useful at restaurants: OO 빼 주세요 (please leave out OO). Also means to subtract in math.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to fall / to drop / to run out
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I dropped my phone and the screen cracked.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Multiple meanings: 물건이 떨어지다 (an object falls), 배터리가 떨어지다 (battery runs out), 시험에 떨어지다 (to fail an exam), 떨어뜨리다 (to drop something, causative form).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The elevator was broken, so I went up by stairs.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 올라 (up) + 가다 (go). Opposite of 내려가다 (to go down). 가격이 올라가다 means 'the price goes up.' 올라오다 means 'to come up.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: To take the subway, go down the stairs.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 내려 (down) + 가다 (go). Opposite of 올라가다 (to go up). 온도가 내려가다 means 'the temperature goes down.' 내려오다 means 'to come down.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: When I go inside the house, I wash my hands.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 들어 (in) + 가다 (go). Opposite of 나가다 (to go out). 들어오다 means 'to come in.' 들어가세요 means 'please go in.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'll go outside for a bit. I'll be right back.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 나 (out) + 가다 (go). Opposite of 들어가다 (to go in). 나오다 means 'to come out.' 나가세요 means 'please go out.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: When will you come back to Korea?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 돌아 (back/around) + 오다 (come). 돌아가다 means 'to go back.' 돌아오세요 means 'please come back.' Also used figuratively: 정신이 돌아오다 (to come to one's senses).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I need to take the child to the hospital.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for taking people or animals, not objects (for objects, use 가져가다). 데려가다 implies leading someone along with you.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Can I bring a friend to the party?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used for bringing people or animals, not objects (for objects, use 가져오다). 데려오다 implies bringing someone along with you.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I sent an email. Please check it.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 메시지를 보내다 (send a message), 택배를 보내다 (send a package), 시간을 보내다 (spend time). Very versatile verb.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I called a taxi. It will come soon.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Two main meanings: 이름을 부르다 (to call a name), 노래를 부르다 (to sing a song). 불러 주세요 can mean 'please call for me' or 'please sing for me.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please answer the teacher's question.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 對答 meaning 'counter-answer.' 대답 is the noun. Also 답하다 (shorter form), 대답을 하다 (to give an answer). 응답하다 is more formal.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please explain this word in a simple way.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 說明 meaning 'speak clearly.' 설명 is the noun. 설명서 means 'instruction manual.' 설명을 듣다 means 'to listen to an explanation.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to promise / to make an appointment
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: We promised to meet tomorrow.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 약속 means both 'promise' and 'appointment/plans.' 약속이 있어요 means 'I have plans.' 약속을 지키다 means 'to keep a promise.' 약속을 잡다 means 'to set up plans.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example: 여행 준비 다 했어요? 내일 출발이에요.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Are you all done preparing for the trip? We depart tomorrow.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 準備 meaning 'arrange in advance.' 준비 is the noun. 준비되다 means 'to be ready.' 마음의 준비 means 'mental preparation.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to organize / to tidy up / to sort out
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I need to tidy up my room. It's too messy.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 整理 meaning 'put in order.' 정리정돈 means 'neat and tidy.' 생각을 정리하다 means 'to organize one's thoughts.' 짐을 정리하다 means 'to pack/unpack.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to confirm / to check / to verify
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please confirm the reservation.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 確認 meaning 'certain recognition.' Very useful in daily life. 확인했어요 means 'I checked/confirmed.' Used constantly in work and everyday situations.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to reserve / to book / to make a reservation
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I reserved a restaurant. We can go at 7.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 豫約 meaning 'arrange in advance.' 예약 is the noun. 예약이 됐어요 means 'the reservation is confirmed.' 예약 취소 means 'reservation cancellation.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I divide the cake into four pieces.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 나누다 has two main meanings: to divide (split) and to share (이야기를 나누다 = to share a conversation).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Collecting stamps is my hobby.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 돈을 모으다 = to save money, 용기를 모으다 = to gather courage. Intransitive form: 모이다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please fill the cup with water.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Causative of 차다 (to become full). 배를 채우다 = to fill one's stomach.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I need to empty the trash can.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Causative of 비다 (to be empty). Opposite of 채우다. 마음을 비우다 = to empty one's mind.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I lock the door before going out.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 문을 잠그다 = to lock the door. Passive: 잠기다. 수도를 잠그다 = to turn off the tap.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I hid the present inside the closet.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Transitive: 숨기다 (to hide something). Intransitive: 숨다 (to hide oneself).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I discovered a new great restaurant!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: More formal/dramatic than 찾다. Often used for unexpected or significant discoveries.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please choose just one from the menu.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 선택 = choice/selection. More formal than 고르다 which is more casual.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example: 아직 뭘 할지 결정 못 했어요.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I haven't decided what to do yet.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 결정 = decision. 결정되다 = to be decided. 결정을 내리다 = to make a decision (formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I couldn't hold back my laughter.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 참을성 = patience. Used for holding back emotions, pain, or urges. 더 이상 못 참겠어요 = I can't take it anymore.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Never give up!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 포기 = giving up. Very commonly used. 포기하고 싶어요 = I want to give up.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I finally succeeded on the exam!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 성공 = success. Opposite of 실패하다. 성공적 = successful (adjective).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I failed on the first try.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 실패 = failure. 실패는 성공의 어머니 = failure is the mother of success (Korean proverb).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to make an effort; to try hard
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I make an effort to study Korean every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 노력 = effort. Koreans highly value 노력. 노력한 만큼 결과가 나와요 = you get results as much as you try.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Happy birthday!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 축하 = congratulations. 축하해요 / 축하드려요 (more polite). Used for birthdays, weddings, promotions, etc.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm always cheering for you!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 응원 = cheering/support. 응원 메시지 = supportive message. Very commonly used to encourage someone.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to lie; to tell a lie
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: You shouldn't lie!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 거짓말 = a lie. 거짓말쟁이 = liar. 새빨간 거짓말 = a bald-faced lie.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I was worried because you suddenly disappeared.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Intransitive verb. Opposite of 나타나다. 흔적도 없이 사라지다 = to vanish without a trace.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: You finally showed up!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Intransitive verb. Opposite of 사라지다. Can mean to appear physically or to emerge/become visible.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to increase; to grow; to improve
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: My Korean skills have improved a lot.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Intransitive. Transitive form: 늘리다. 체중이 늘다 = to gain weight. 실력이 늘다 = to improve skills.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The number of customers has decreased a lot lately.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Intransitive. Transitive form: 줄이다. Opposite of 늘다. 시간을 줄이다 = to reduce time.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Our team won 3 to 1!
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 지다. 유혹을 이기다 = to overcome temptation. 3 대 1 = 3 to 1 (score).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: We lost by a narrow margin.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Opposite of 이기다. 아깝게 지다 = to narrowly lose. Also means 'to set' (해가 지다 = sun sets).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: It ended in a 2-2 tie.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Used in sports and games. 무승부 is the noun form meaning 'a draw/tie.'

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I graduated from university last year.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: 졸업 = graduation. 졸업식 = graduation ceremony. Opposite: 입학하다 = to enroll/enter school.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: The weather is very nice today.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Neutral/standard 'very.' Can be used in both spoken and written Korean.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: This issue is very important.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More formal than 아주. Common in news, reports, and formal writing.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: This food is really delicious.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Polite but natural in conversation. 정말요? = Really? (with surprise).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's really fun!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More casual than 정말. Also used as a noun meaning 'the real thing.' 진짜? = For real?

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please help me (a bit).
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Short for 조금. Also softens requests: 좀 비켜 주세요 sounds gentler than without 좀.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please give me just a little water.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More formal/full form of 좀. 조금씩 = little by little.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please eat a lot. (Enjoy your meal.)
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Adverb form of 많다. 많이 드세요 is a common polite phrase when serving food.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Come quickly!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Adverb form of 빠르다. 빨리빨리 (hurry hurry) is a famous Korean cultural concept.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please speak slowly.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Essential phrase for language learners. Opposite: 빨리.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: You speak Korean well.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Opposite: 못. 잘 먹겠습니다 = I will eat well (said before meals). 잘 지내요? = How are you?

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I can't go today.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Placed before the verb. 못하다 = to be bad at. 못 vs 안: 못 = can't, 안 = don't/won't.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I don't eat meat.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Placed before the verb for negation. For 하다 verbs: 공부 안 해요 (not 안 공부해요).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: See you again!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 또 can link items: 사과, 또 바나나 = apples, and also bananas.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Please say it one more time.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 다시 implies repeating. 또 implies something additional or recurring. Subtle difference.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I already ate.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Neutral 'already.' States a fact without surprise. Compare with 벌써.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's not finished yet.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 아직 + positive = still. 아직 + negative = not yet. 아직도 adds emphasis.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's already 12 o'clock?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Unlike 이미, 벌써 carries surprise or disbelief that something happened so soon.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I'm always grateful.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: From 한자 恒常. 언제나 is a native Korean synonym.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I come to this restaurant often.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Between 항상 (always) and 가끔 (sometimes) in frequency.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: What time do you usually wake up?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Also an adjective meaning 'ordinary/average.' 보통이 아니다 = not ordinary (exceptional).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I sometimes watch movies.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Less frequent than 자주. 가끔씩 is a slightly emphasized form.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I absolutely never lie.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 절대(로) + negative verb = never. From 한자 絶對. 절대로 is the full adverb form.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I don't understand at all.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Always used with negative verbs. From 한자 全. Adds strong emphasis to negation.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: The homework is almost done.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 거의 다 = almost all/everything. 거의 안 = hardly/barely.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It will probably rain tomorrow.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Often paired with -(으)ㄹ 거예요 (future guess). Less certain than 확실히 (certainly).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: You must come! / Make sure to come!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Used for emphasis in requests and promises. 꼭 해야 돼요 = You definitely have to do it.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Wash your hands first.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 먼저 가세요 = Please go first (polite). Also means 'before (someone else).'

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I'll call you later.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 나중 = later time (noun). Opposite: 먼저. 나중에 봐요 = See you later.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Do you want to eat lunch together?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 같이 is casual/spoken; 함께 is more formal/written. Both are very common.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I travel alone.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 혼자서 adds emphasis. 혼자 살다 = to live alone. Opposite: 같이/함께.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I'll go right away.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Multiple uses: 바로 여기 = right here; 바로 그거예요 = That's exactly it.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It suddenly rained.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Very common in storytelling. 갑작스럽다 is the adjective form (sudden).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: The exam is finally over!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Implies waiting/anticipation. Positive nuance: something long-awaited happened.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I drank coffee, and then took a walk.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Connects sentences. For connecting nouns, use 하고 or (이)랑 instead.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It rained. So I took an umbrella.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Shows cause → result. Connects two sentences where the first is the reason.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I want to go. But I don't have time.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Shortened to 근데 in casual speech. Can also change topics (by the way).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 어렵지만 재미있어요. 하지만 시간이 더 필요해요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's difficult but fun. However, I need more time.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More formal/written than 그런데. Purely contrasting (doesn't change topic).

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).english: then, if so, in that case
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 배고프다고요? 그러면 같이 밥 먹으러 가요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: You're hungry? Then let's go eat together.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Shortened to 그럼 in casual speech. Responds to a condition or statement.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's hard. But still, I won't give up.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Acknowledges a difficulty but continues anyway. Very common in daily speech.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I couldn't go. Because I was sick.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Gives a reason for the previous statement. Often paired with -거든요 at the end of the explanation.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It takes roughly about thirty minutes.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Slightly more formal than 약; 대략적으로 = approximately (longer form)

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: What time exactly are we meeting?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 정확하다 = to be accurate; 정확히 말하면 = to be precise

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I clearly put it here but it's gone.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 분명하다 = to be clear/certain; used to emphasize certainty

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Can you definitely finish it by tomorrow?
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 확실하다 = to be certain; stronger than 아마 (maybe)

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Honestly speaking, it's a bit expensive.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 솔직하다 = to be honest; 솔직히 말해서 = to be frank

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 한국 음식 중에 특히 불고기를 좋아해요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Among Korean foods, I especially like bulgogi.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 특별히 is a synonym but 특히 is more common in speech

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: On weekends I mostly rest at home.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 주 = main; similar to 대부분 but emphasizes habitual behavior

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: In the end, it rained so we couldn't go.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 결 = conclusion + 국 = situation; implies a final outcome after a process

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: At last, the exam is over!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More dramatic/literary than 드디어; emphasizes a long-awaited result

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 서울은 비가 왔어요. 한편, 부산은 맑았어요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It rained in Seoul. Meanwhile, it was sunny in Busan.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 한 = one + 편 = side; used to introduce a contrasting or parallel point

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).english: moreover / besides / on top of that
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's raining, and on top of that, it's windy.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Adds additional information, usually reinforcing the previous point

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 비가 많이 와요. 따라서 우산을 가져가세요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: It's raining a lot. Therefore, take an umbrella.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: More formal than 그래서; common in writing and presentations

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).english: that is / namely / in other words
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Tomorrow, that is, Monday, we start.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Used to rephrase or clarify; 즉, = i.e.

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 과일을 좋아해요. 예를 들면, 사과나 딸기요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I like fruit. For example, apples or strawberries.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 예 = example + 들다 = to give; also shortened to 예를 들어

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example: 형은 키가 커요. 반면에 저는 작아요.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: My older brother is tall. On the other hand, I'm short.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 반면 = opposite side; used to contrast two different things

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: I was worried, but it was actually fun instead.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Indicates the opposite of what was expected; a surprising contrast

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Anyway, we have to do it.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Used to dismiss previous discussion and move on; casual tone

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Of course I'll help!
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 물 = no + 론 = argument; literally 'no argument about it'

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: Actually, I don't really know either.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: 사실은 (with topic marker) = the truth is; very common conversation opener

자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).example_en: In any case, good work.
자주 쓰는 부사 & 접속사 (Adverbs & Conjunctions).notes: Similar to 어쨌든 but slightly more casual; wraps up a discussion

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example: 우리 집에 개가 한 마리 있어요.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: We have one dog at our house.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The counter for animals is 마리. 강아지 means puppy.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The cat is sleeping on the sofa.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Can be shortened to 냥이 in casual speech. 야옹 is the Korean onomatopoeia for meowing.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: A bird is singing on top of the tree.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 새 also means new' in other contexts. 참새 is a sparrow, 독수리 is an eagle.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I caught a fish in the river.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Literally 물 (water) + 고기 (meat). 생선 refers to fish as food at a market.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The rabbit is eating a carrot.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: In Korean folklore, a rabbit lives on the moon making rice cakes (떡).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example: 산에서 곰을 보면 절대 뛰면 안 돼요.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: If you see a bear on the mountain, you must never run.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The bear is significant in Korean mythology (단군 신화). 곰 also colloquially means a slow or clumsy person.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Long ago, tigers lived in the mountains.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The tiger is a symbol of Korea. The proverb 호랑이도 제 말 하면 온다 means 'speak of the devil.'

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: They say the lion is the king of animals.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 사자 (lion) should not be confused with 사자 (四字) meaning four characters, as in 사자성어.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: An elephant's nose (trunk) is really long.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Literally related to 코 (nose). Korean children often learn to draw elephants early.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The monkey eats bananas up in the tree.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 원숭이 is one of the 12 zodiac animals (십이지). The zodiac year is 신년.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Many people are afraid of snakes.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Also a zodiac animal. 독사 means venomous snake. 뱀 is used metaphorically for a treacherous person.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The turtle walks slowly.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 거북 is the base form; 거북이 adds the friendly suffix -이. Appears in the folk tale 토끼와 거북이.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I saw a mouse in the kitchen!
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 쥐 is also the first of the 12 zodiac animals. 생쥐 specifically means a small house mouse.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I tried riding a horse on Jeju Island.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 말 also means 'words/speech.' Context distinguishes them. 경마 means horse racing.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: If you go to the countryside, there are many cows.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 한우 means Korean beef cattle, a premium product. 소고기 is beef.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The pig is playing in the mud.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 돼지고기 means pork. Dreaming of a pig in Korean culture is considered lucky (a sign of wealth).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The chicken crowed in the morning.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 닭고기 is chicken meat. 치킨 specifically refers to fried chicken. The ㄹ in 닭 is silent before consonants.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Ducks are swimming in the park pond.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 오리고기 is duck meat, a popular dish in Korea. 꽥꽥 is the Korean onomatopoeia for quacking.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example: 잠이 안 올 때 양을 세요.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: When you can't sleep, count sheep.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 양 also means 'amount' or 'Western' (洋) in other contexts. 양고기 is lamb/mutton.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: In spring, many pretty butterflies fly around.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 나비넥타이 means bow tie (butterfly necktie). 나비 is a common poetic image in Korean literature.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Bees collect honey from flowers.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 벌 also means 'punishment.' 꿀벌 specifically means honeybee. 벌꿀 means bee honey.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The ants are walking in a line.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 개미처럼 일하다 means to work like an ant (to work very hard). Used to describe diligent people.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The spider is spinning a web.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 거미줄 means spider web. 거미 sounds similar to 거북이 so be careful with pronunciation.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: In summer, there are too many mosquitoes.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 모기에 물리다 means to be bitten by a mosquito. 모기향 is mosquito-repellent incense.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I'm resting under a tree.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 나무 also means 'wood' as a material. 나뭇잎 means tree leaf (note the ㅅ linking sound).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I gave flowers as a gift to my girlfriend.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 꽃집 is a flower shop. 꽃다발 is a bouquet. The ㅊ is pronounced before vowels but silent before consonants.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The children are running and playing on the grass.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 풀 also means 'glue' in a different context. 풀밭 means a grassy field or lawn.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: In autumn, the leaves turn red.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 나뭇잎 is tree leaf. 잎사귀 is another word for leaf, slightly more literary.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I went to the mountain with friends on the weekend.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 등산 means hiking/mountain climbing, a hugely popular hobby in Korea. 산책 means a walk.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I rode a bicycle along the Han River.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 한강 (Han River) runs through Seoul. 강변 means riverside. 강물 means river water.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I want to go to the sea in summer.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 해변 means beach/seashore. Korea is a peninsula so the sea is culturally very important.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The lake is really beautiful.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Sino-Korean word: 湖 (lake) + 水 (water). 호숫가 means lakeside.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Jeju Island is the largest island in Korea.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Korea has over 3,000 islands. 무인도 means uninhabited island.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: It's hard to find water in the desert.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Sino-Korean: 沙 (sand) + 漠 (vast). 사막화 means desertification.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Walking in the forest makes you feel better.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 산림욕 means forest bathing, a popular wellness activity in Korea. 숲속 means inside the forest.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The sky is really clear today.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 하늘색 means sky blue. 하늘 can also poetically mean heaven or the divine.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The ground is wet because it rained.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 땅 also means land or territory. 땅속 means underground. 땅콩 means peanut (ground nut).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I picked up a pretty stone from the river.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 돌 also means a baby's first birthday (돌잔치). 돌담 means a stone wall.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The children are making a castle out of sand.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 모래사장 means sandy beach. 모래시계 means hourglass (sand clock).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The waves are really high today.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 파도타기 means surfing (wave riding). 파도 소리 means the sound of waves.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: You can hear the refreshing sound of water from the waterfall.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Sino-Korean: 瀑 (waterfall) + 布 (spread). 폭포수 means waterfall water.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: A rainbow appeared after the rain stopped.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 무지개색 means rainbow colors. 무지갯빛 means iridescent or rainbow-hued.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I bought one red rose.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The counter for flowers is 송이. 장미꽃 specifically emphasizes the flower of the rose.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Sunflowers always look toward the sun.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Literally 해 (sun) + 바라기 (one who gazes at). A poetically descriptive Korean word.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Let's go see cherry blossoms in spring.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 벚꽃 놀이 means cherry blossom viewing. 여의도 in Seoul is famous for its cherry blossom festival.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The autumn leaves on the mountain are really pretty.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 단풍놀이 means autumn leaf viewing. 설악산 and 내장산 are famous for 단풍 in Korea.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The children want to go to the zoo.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 동물 (animal) + 원 (園, garden). 서울대공원 has one of the largest zoos in Korea.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I watched a dolphin show at the aquarium.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Sino-Korean: 水 (water) + 族 (group) + 館 (building). Also called 아쿠아리움.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I want to raise a pet.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The newer preferred term is 반려동물 (companion animal), reflecting a shift in how Koreans view pets.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I walk the puppy every evening.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 산책 (walk) + 시키다 (to make/have someone do). The causative form makes it 'to have the pet walk.'

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: An eagle is flying high in the sky.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: A large bird of prey. 대머리 독수리 is a bald eagle. Often symbolizes strength and freedom.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: A crow is sitting on the power line.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: In Korean superstition, hearing a crow in the morning is considered a bad omen. 까악까악 is the Korean onomatopoeia for cawing.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Sparrows are eating bread crumbs.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: One of the most common birds in Korea. The proverb 참새가 방앗간을 그냥 지나랴 means 'a sparrow can't pass a mill' (can't resist temptation).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: There are too many pigeons in the park.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Very common in Korean cities. 평화의 비둘기 means 'dove of peace.' Many Koreans find urban pigeons a nuisance.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The parrot imitates human speech.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 앵무새처럼 따라 하다 means to repeat like a parrot. 앵무 comes from the Chinese characters 鸚鵡.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Penguins can't fly but they swim well.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: Loanword from English. Very popular as cute characters in Korean media and merchandise.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I saw a whale in the sea near Jeju Island.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The proverb 고래 싸움에 새우 등 터진다 means 'when whales fight, the shrimp's back breaks' (innocents suffer in others' conflicts).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: The dolphin jumped out of the water.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 돌 (spinning/turning) + 고래 (whale). Jeju Island is known for wild dolphin sightings.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Sharks are scary but cool animals.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: The children's song 아기상어 (Baby Shark) became a global phenomenon from Korea. 상어지느러미 is shark fin.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: An octopus has eight legs.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 문어 also means 'written language' (文語) in a different context. 산낙지 is live small octopus, a Korean delicacy.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I caught a small crab at the beach.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 꽃게 is a blue crab, popular in Korean cuisine. 간장게장 (soy sauce marinated crab) is called 밥도둑 (rice thief) because it makes you eat so much rice.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: I've seen a deer on the mountain.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 사슴벌레 is a stag beetle. 나라의 사슴 공원 (Nara Deer Park) is a popular travel destination for Koreans visiting Japan.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Foxes are very smart animals.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: In Korean folklore, 구미호 (nine-tailed fox) is a mythical creature that can transform into a beautiful woman. 여우같다 means crafty or sly.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Wolves appear often in old stories.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 늑대인간 means werewolf. The expression 양의 탈을 쓴 늑대 means 'a wolf in sheep's clothing.'

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: A squirrel is eating acorns up in the tree.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 다람쥐 챗바퀴 돌듯 means going around like a squirrel wheel, describing a busy but repetitive life. 도토리 means acorn.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Bats are animals that are active at night.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: In Korean folklore, 박쥐 is seen as two-faced because it claimed to be both a bird and a mammal. 박쥐같다 means indecisive or two-faced.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Dragonflies fly around a lot in autumn.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 잠자리 also means 'sleeping spot/bed' in a different context. 고추잠자리 is a red dragonfly, a symbol of autumn in Korea.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: A ladybug landed on my hand.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 무당 means shaman, and the ladybug's bright colors resemble a shaman's outfit. Considered a lucky insect in many cultures.

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example: 비가 온 후에 지렁이가 땅 위로 나와요.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: Earthworms come above ground after it rains.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 지렁이도 밟으면 꿈틀한다 is a proverb meaning even an earthworm will squirm when stepped on (even meek people have limits).

동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).example_en: You need to be careful of jellyfish at the beach in summer.
동물 & 자연 (Animals & Nature).notes: 해파리에 쏘이다 means to be stung by a jellyfish. Some Korean beaches post jellyfish warnings during summer.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Today's Korean class was fun.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 수업을 듣다 means to take a class. 수업을 하다 means to teach a class.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I haven't finished all my homework yet.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 숙제를 하다 means to do homework. 숙제를 내다 means to assign homework.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example: 다음 주에 시험이 있어서 공부해야 돼요.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I have to study because there's an exam next week.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 시험을 보다 means to take a test. 시험을 치르다 is a more formal variant.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: My grades went up a lot this semester.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 성적표 is a report card. Grades are extremely important in Korean education culture.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Please open your textbook to page 30.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 교과 (curriculum) + 서 (書, book). 참고서 means a reference book or study guide.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I wrote down the important content in my notebook.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Also called 노트. 공책 is more traditional; 노트 is the loanword version commonly used.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example: 연필로 먼저 쓰고 나중에 펜으로 써요.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: First write with pencil, then later write with pen.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Sino-Korean: 鉛 (lead) + 筆 (writing tool). 색연필 means colored pencil.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Can you lend me just one ballpoint pen?
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 볼 (ball) + 펜 (pen). In formal writing contexts, Koreans often use 검정 볼펜 (black ballpoint pen).

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I erased the wrong part with an eraser.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: From 지우다 (to erase) + -개 (tool suffix). 화이트 (white-out) is used for pen mistakes.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: The teacher is writing on the blackboard.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Many Korean schools now use 화이트보드 (whiteboard) or 스마트보드 instead.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Please cut the paper with scissors.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 가위 is also the word for scissors in 가위바위보 (rock-paper-scissors). 가위눌림 means sleep paralysis.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I'm gluing the paper with glue.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Same pronunciation as 풀 (grass) but different meaning. 딱풀 means glue stick.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Please give me just one sheet of paper.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: The counter for paper is 장. 한지 is traditional Korean paper, famous for its durability.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I do my homework on the computer.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 노트북 means laptop in Korean (not notebook). PC방 is a Korean internet cafe.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I printed the report with the printer.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 출력하다 or 인쇄하다 means to print. 프린트 can mean both printer and printout.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: The classroom is on the third floor.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 교 (教, teaching) + 실 (室, room). Korean schools number floors starting from 1, not ground floor.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: If you review every day, your skills improve.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 복 (復, again) + 습 (習, study). The opposite is 예습 (preview/preparation).

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I previewed the content we'll learn tomorrow.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 예 (豫, beforehand) + 습 (習, study). 예습과 복습 (preview and review) is a common study phrase.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I have to give a presentation in class tomorrow.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 발표하다 means to present or announce. 발표 자료 means presentation materials.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example: 오늘 수업에서 환경 문제에 대해 토론했어요.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: We discussed environmental issues in class today.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 토론하다 means to discuss/debate. 토론 대회 is a debate competition.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: If you have a question, please raise your hand.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 질문하다 means to ask a question. 질문 있으세요? is 'Do you have any questions?'

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I couldn't answer the teacher's question.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 대답하다 means to answer/reply. 정답 means the correct answer. 오답 means wrong answer.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: The teacher explained the grammar easily for us.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 설명하다 means to explain. 설명서 means an instruction manual.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Can you understand this sentence?
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 이해가 되다 means 'it is understood' (more natural than 이해하다 in many contexts). 이해력 means comprehension ability.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Memorizing Chinese characters is the hardest.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 암기하다 is a more formal synonym. 외워야 할 것이 많아요 means 'there's a lot to memorize.'

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Please translate this sentence into English.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 번역 is translation (written). 통역 is interpretation (spoken). 번역가 is a translator.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I practice pronunciation every day.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 연습 means practice. 연습장 means a practice notebook. 연습 경기 means a practice match.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: The answer is wrong. Please try again.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Often confused with 다르다 (to be different). 틀리다 implies an error; 다르다 simply means different.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Yes, that's correct! It's the right answer.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 맞다 also means 'to be hit' or 'to fit.' 맞아요 is one of the most common Korean affirmative responses.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: My test score is 90 points.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 점 (點, point) + 수 (數, number). 만점 means a perfect score.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I'm really happy that I passed the exam.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 합격하다 means to pass (an exam or test). The opposite is 불합격 (fail).

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Unfortunately, I failed this time.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 불 (不, not) + 합격 (pass). 떨어지다 is a colloquial way to say 'to fail' an exam.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I graduate from university next year.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 졸업식 is a graduation ceremony. 졸업하다 means to graduate.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I enroll in elementary school in March.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 입 (入, enter) + 학 (學, study). The Korean school year starts in March, not September.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I'm taking 5 subjects this semester.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Korean universities have two semesters: 1학기 (March-June) and 2학기 (September-December).

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: What are you going to do during vacation?
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 여름 방학 is summer vacation, 겨울 방학 is winter vacation. 방학하다 means to go on school break.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: My favorite subject is math.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 과 (科, subject) + 목 (目, item). 필수 과목 means required subject; 선택 과목 means elective.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I'm solving math problems.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 수 (數, number) + 학 (學, study). 수학자 means mathematician. Korean students typically study math intensively.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Doing science experiments is fun.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 과 (科, branch) + 학 (學, study). 과학자 is a scientist. 과학관 is a science museum.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I'm very interested in Korean history.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 역 (歷, pass through) + 사 (史, history). 역사적 means historical. 한국사 is Korean history.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I study English every day.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 영 (英, Britain) + 어 (語, language). English education is a massive industry in Korea.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: It's been one year since I started learning Korean.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 한국 (Korea) + 어 (語, language). TOPIK is the official Korean language proficiency test.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: We sang songs during music class.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 음 (音, sound) + 악 (樂, music). 음악 also means music in general. 음악가 is a musician.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: We painted watercolors during art class.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 미 (美, beauty) + 술 (術, skill/art). 미술관 means art museum. 미술가 means artist.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: We played soccer during P.E. class.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 체 (體, body) + 육 (育, nurture). 체육관 means gymnasium. 체육대회 is a sports day event.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I take notes diligently during class.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 필기하다 = to take notes. 필기시험 means a written exam (as opposed to 실기시험, a practical exam). 필기구 means writing instruments.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Memorizing English words is hard.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 암기하다 = to memorize. More formal than 외우다. 암 (暗, dark) + 기 (記, record) — learning in one's mind without looking.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Korean grammar is very different from English.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 문 (文, writing) + 법 (法, rule/method). 문법적으로 means grammatically. Korean is an SOV (subject-object-verb) language.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I memorize 10 words a day.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 단 (單, single) + 어 (語, word). 단어장 is a vocabulary notebook or flashcard set. 어휘 is a broader term meaning vocabulary overall.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: My Korean pronunciation has improved a lot.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 발음하다 = to pronounce. Korean has many pronunciation rules like 연음 (liaison), 경음화 (tensification), and 비음화 (nasalization).

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: The listening test is the hardest.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: From 듣다 (to listen). One of the four language skills tested in TOPIK. 듣기 평가 = listening assessment.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I want to practice speaking a lot.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: From 말하다 (to speak). 말하기 대회 = speech contest. Speaking is often the most challenging skill for language learners.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: My reading speed is gradually getting faster.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: From 읽다 (to read). 읽기 자료 = reading material. The ㄹ in 읽다 is silent in pronunciation (익다).

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I haven't finished my writing homework yet.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: From 쓰다 (to write). 쓰기 also appears in TOPIK as a test section. 글쓰기 is a more literary term for writing composition.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I take Korean conversation classes every week.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 회 (會, meet) + 화 (話, speech). 영어 회화 = English conversation. 회화 학원 = conversation academy.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: This problem is too difficult.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Can mean a test question or a problem/issue. 문제를 풀다 = to solve a problem. 문제집 = workbook/problem set.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: They give a prize if you get the correct answer.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 정 (正, correct) + 답 (答, answer). 정답률 = accuracy rate. The opposite is 오답.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I make a wrong-answer notebook and review it.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 오 (誤, wrong) + 답 (答, answer). 오답 노트 is a popular study method in Korea where students record their mistakes to review later.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: The teacher handed out the model answers.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 모범 (model/exemplary) + 답안 (answer sheet). Students compare their answers to the 모범답안 after exams.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: If you cheat on the test, you get a zero.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: Konglish from 'cunning.' 커닝하다 = to cheat on an exam. 부정행위 is the formal term for cheating/academic dishonesty.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I received a scholarship because my grades were good.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 장학 (獎學, encouraging study) + 금 (金, money). 전액 장학금 = full scholarship. 반액 장학금 = half scholarship.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: Korean university tuition is very expensive.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 등록 (registration) + 금 (money). 등록금을 내다 = to pay tuition. Tuition costs are a major social issue in Korea.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I received a business degree from university.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 학 (學, study) + 위 (位, rank). 학위를 취득하다 = to obtain a degree. 학사 = bachelor's, 석사 = master's, 박사 = doctorate.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: I'm researching Korean in a master's program.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 석 (碩, great) + 사 (士, scholar). 석사 학위 = master's degree. 석사 논문 = master's thesis. Takes about 2 years in Korea.

학교 & 공부 (School & Study).example_en: It took 5 years to get my doctorate.
학교 & 공부 (School & Study).notes: 박 (博, broad/extensive) + 사 (士, scholar). 박사님 is used as an honorific for PhD holders. Koreans highly respect doctoral degrees.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I go to work at 8 a.m. every morning.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 출 (出, go out) + 근 (勤, work). 출근길 means the commute to work.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I left work early today.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 퇴 (退, retreat) + 근 (勤, work). 퇴근 시간 means quitting time.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: There's a meeting at 2 p.m.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 회의실 means meeting room. 화상 회의 means video conference.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I have to submit the report by tomorrow.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 보고 (report) + 서 (書, document). 보고하다 means to report to a superior.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Please check your email.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 이메일을 보내다 means to send an email. 이메일을 받다 means to receive an email.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: A phone call came from the client.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 전화하다 means to make a phone call. 전화를 받다 means to answer the phone.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: We exchange business cards when meeting for the first time.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 명 (名, name) + 함 (銜, title). In Korean business culture, give and receive cards with both hands.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The salary comes in on the 25th.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 월 (月, month) + 급 (給, pay). 월급날 means payday. Most Korean companies pay monthly.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I received a bonus at the end of the year.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Also called 상여금 in formal/Sino-Korean. Many Korean companies give bonuses at Lunar New Year and Chuseok.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm going to take vacation next month.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 휴가를 내다 means to submit a vacation request. 연차 means annual leave days.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm going on a business trip to Busan next week.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 출 (出, go out) + 장 (張, extend). 해외 출장 means overseas business trip.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example: 이번 주에 야근을 세 번이나 했어요.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I worked overtime three times this week.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 야 (夜, night) + 근 (勤, work). Overtime work culture has been a major social issue in Korea.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I eat lunch together with my colleagues.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 동 (同, same) + 료 (僚, companion). 직장 동료 specifically means work colleague.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I showed the report to my boss.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 상 (上, above) + 사 (司, manage). Honorific language is essential when speaking to 상사 in Korean.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I entrusted the work to my subordinate.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 부 (部, part) + 하 (下, below). The term 후배 (junior) is often used more naturally in daily speech.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The team leader led the meeting.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 팀 (team) + 장 (長, chief). Always add 님 when addressing: 팀장님.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The CEO is on a business trip today.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 사 (社, company) + 장 (長, chief) + 님 (honorific). Used for the owner or top executive of a company.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm nervous because I have an interview tomorrow.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 면 (面, face) + 접 (接, meet). 면접관 is the interviewer. 면접을 보다 means to have an interview.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I submitted my resume online.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 이력 (career history) + 서 (書, document). 자기소개서 is a self-introduction letter, also required in Korea.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I got a job after graduating from university.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 취 (就, approach) + 직 (職, job). 취직하다 means to get employed. 취업 is the broader concept of employment.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: My father is retiring next year.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 퇴 (退, retreat) + 직 (職, job). 퇴직금 means severance pay. 정년퇴직 means mandatory retirement.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I got promoted by working hard.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 승 (昇, rise) + 진 (進, advance). 승진하다 means to get promoted.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I was fired because the company situation was bad.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 해고하다 means to fire someone. 해고당하다 means to be fired (passive). 정리해고 means layoff.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I signed the contract.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 계약서 is a contract document. 계약직 means contract worker (non-permanent). 정규직 means permanent position.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm busy because the deadline is tomorrow.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 마감일 means the deadline date. 마감하다 means to close or finalize.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: We started a new project.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. Often shortened to 프로젝 in casual speech. 프로젝트 관리 means project management.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm an office worker.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 회사 (company) + 원 (員, member). 직장인 is a broader term for any employed person.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: That person is a famous entrepreneur.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 사업 (business) + 가 (家, expert). 사업을 하다 means to run a business.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm working as a freelancer.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 프리랜서 is increasingly common in Korea, especially in IT and creative fields.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I worked part-time at a cafe when I was a college student.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: From German 'Arbeit.' Often shortened to 알바. 알바생 means part-time worker.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I worked as an intern in the summer.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 인턴십 means internship. Many Korean companies have structured intern programs.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I negotiated my annual salary.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 연 (年, year) + 봉 (俸, salary). 연봉 is stated before tax in Korea. 실수령액 is take-home pay.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: This company has good benefits.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 복 (福, fortune) + 지 (祉, welfare). 복리후생 is the formal term for employee benefits.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Working hours are from 9 to 6.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 근무 (work/duty) + 시간 (time). 유연 근무제 means flexible working hours.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Shall we eat together during lunch break?
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 점심 (lunch) + 시간 (time). Most Korean offices have a lunch break from 12:00 to 1:00.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: There's a team dinner this evening.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 회 (會, gather) + 식 (食, eat). 회식 culture is a significant part of Korean work life, though declining among younger workers.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Work stress has been severe lately.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 스트레스를 받다 means to feel stressed. 스트레스를 풀다 means to relieve stress.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I achieved good results this year.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 성 (成, accomplish) + 과 (果, result). 성과급 means performance-based bonus.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I achieved this quarter's goal.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 목 (目, eye) + 표 (標, mark). 목표를 세우다 means to set a goal.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm organizing the documents.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 서 (書, writing) + 류 (類, type). 서류 가방 means briefcase.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Please make 10 copies of this document.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 복사하다 means to copy/photocopy. 복사기 means photocopier.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Please send the documents by fax.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Fax machines are still used in many Korean offices, especially in government and traditional businesses.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm giving a presentation to the client tomorrow.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Often shortened to PT (피티) in Korean office slang. PPT (피피티) refers to PowerPoint slides.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: We're carrying out the project in cooperation with another team.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 협 (協, together) + 력 (力, power). 협력하다 means to cooperate. 협력업체 means partner company.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Competition is fierce in the job market these days.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 경 (競, compete) + 쟁 (爭, struggle). 경쟁력 means competitiveness. 경쟁자 means competitor.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: If office supplies are running low, tell the general affairs team.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 사무 (office work) + 용품 (supplies). Includes items like pens, paper, stapler, etc. 문구류 is another term for stationery.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The copier broke down, so I requested a repair.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 복사 (copy) + 기 (machine). Also called 복합기 when it combines printing, scanning, and faxing functions.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I scan documents with the scanner and send them by email.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 스캔하다 = to scan. Many offices use all-in-one machines that combine scanning, printing, and copying.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example: 공유 캘린더에 회의 일정을 넣어 주세요.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: Please put the meeting schedule on the shared calendar.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English, typically referring to digital calendars. 달력 is the traditional Korean word for a physical calendar.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: An announcement was posted on the bulletin board.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 게시 (posting) + 판 (board). Also refers to online forums and message boards. 게시글 = a post on a board.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I always wear a name tag at work.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 명 (名, name) + 찰 (札, tag/label). 명찰을 달다 = to wear/attach a name tag. Often required at conferences and offices.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: They check attendance every morning.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 출 (出, appear) + 석 (席, seat). 출석부 = attendance sheet. 출석률 = attendance rate. Used in both school and work.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I was late today because I missed the bus.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 지각하다 = to be late/tardy. 지각 사유서 = late arrival excuse form. Being late is taken seriously in Korean workplaces.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I left early because I wasn't feeling well.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 조 (早, early) + 퇴 (退, retreat). 조퇴하다 = to leave early. You typically need supervisor approval to 조퇴 in Korean workplaces.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I was absent from work today because I was sick.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 결 (缺, lack) + 근 (勤, work). 결근하다 = to be absent from work. 무단결근 = unauthorized absence, which can lead to disciplinary action.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: There's a team workshop next week.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. Often held outside the office as a team-building event. May include training, activities, and social time.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm attending a marketing seminar this afternoon.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 세미나에 참석하다 = to attend a seminar. 세미나실 = seminar room.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: We brainstormed for the new project.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 브레인스토밍하다 = to brainstorm. A common practice in Korean creative and marketing teams.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The teamwork was really great on this project.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 팀워크가 좋다/나쁘다 = teamwork is good/bad. Koreans place high value on group harmony and collaboration.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The project succeeded thanks to the team leader's leadership.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: Loanword from English. 리더십이 있다 = to have leadership. Korean companies increasingly value leadership skills alongside seniority.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I've grown a lot at this company.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 성 (成, become) + 장 (長, long/grow). 성장하다 = to grow. Used for personal development, company growth, and economic growth.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I was assigned to plan a new product.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 기 (企, plan) + 획 (劃, mark/plan). 기획하다 = to plan/propose. 기획팀 = planning team. 기획서 = project proposal.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: The budget for this project is insufficient.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 예 (豫, beforehand) + 산 (算, calculate). 예산을 세우다 = to set a budget. 예산 초과 = over budget.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example: 이번 달 매출이 지난달보다 많이 올랐어요.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: This month's sales went up a lot compared to last month.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 매 (賣, sell) + 출 (出, out). 매출액 = sales revenue amount. 매출 목표 = sales target.

직장 & 일 (Work & Office).example_en: I'm planning to invest in that company.
직장 & 일 (Work & Office).notes: 투 (投, throw) + 자 (資, resources). 투자하다 = to invest. 투자자 = investor. 주식 투자 = stock investment.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I clean my room every weekend.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: General term for cleaning any space; often paired with a location (방, 집, 화장실, etc.)

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: The weather is nice, so I'm doing laundry.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 빨래 alone means 'laundry' (the clothes); 빨래를 널다 means to hang laundry to dry

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I do the dishes after dinner.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 설거지 refers specifically to washing dishes; 설거지통 is a dish basin

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Today I'm cooking.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: More formal/general than 밥하다 (to make rice/meal); 요리 alone means 'cooking' or 'a dish'

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I iron my shirt before going to work.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 다리미 is the iron (appliance); 다림질 is the act of ironing

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I sweep the yard with a broom.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Irregular verb: 쓸다 → 쓸어요; 빗자루 means broom

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I wipe the table clean.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Also used for brushing teeth (이를 닦다) and polishing shoes (구두를 닦다)

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I'm tidying up the desk.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Broad meaning: organize, arrange, sort, or put things in order

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: In Korea, you must do recycling.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Literally 'separated collection'; Korea has strict recycling rules by material type

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Please throw away the trash.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 쓰레기를 버리다 = to throw away trash; 음식물 쓰레기 = food waste

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Where is the trash can?
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 통 means 'bin' or 'container'; 쓰레기통 = trash + container

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: We ran out of detergent.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 주방 세제 = dish soap; 세탁 세제 = laundry detergent

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I wash my hands well with soap.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Refers to bar soap; 물비누 or 핸드워시 is liquid/hand soap

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: This shampoo smells nice.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 린스 (rinse) is the Korean term for conditioner

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I'll bring a new towel.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Also written 타월 (from English 'towel'); 손수건 = handkerchief

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I squeeze toothpaste onto the toothbrush.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 치 means 'tooth' and 약 means 'medicine/paste'

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I change my toothbrush every 3 months.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 치 (tooth) + 솔 (brush); 전동 칫솔 = electric toothbrush

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I get dressed while looking in the mirror.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 거울을 보다 = to look in the mirror

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I comb my hair with a comb.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 빗다 (to comb) and 빗 (comb) share the same root; 머리를 빗다 = to comb one's hair

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I dry my hair with a hair dryer after showering.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Also called 헤어드라이어; 머리를 말리다 = to dry one's hair

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I put the laundry in the washing machine.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 세탁 = washing/laundering; 건조기 = dryer

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Please put the milk in the refrigerator.
