집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 냉 = cold, 장 = storage, 고 = warehouse; 냉동고/냉동실 = freezer

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I heat up rice in the microwave.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 전자 = electronic; 데우다 = to heat up/warm

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: It's too hot, so I turn on the air conditioner.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Short for 에어컨디셔너; 켜다 = to turn on, 끄다 = to turn off

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: A heater is essential in winter.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Also 난방 (heating system); 온풍기 is another word for space heater

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: It's cool when I turn on the fan.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 선풍기를 틀다 = to turn on a fan; 틀다 is used for appliances

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I turn on the light when I enter the room.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 전 = electricity, 등 = lamp; 형광등 = fluorescent light

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I plug the charger into the outlet.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: From the German/Dutch word 'Konzentration'; 꽂다 = to plug in, 빼다 = to unplug

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I change the channel with the remote control.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Short for 리모트 컨트롤; commonly used for TV, AC, etc.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I put the key in my bag.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 열다 (to open) + 쇠 (metal); 카드키 is a key card

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I locked the lock on the door.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 잠그다 = to lock; 열다 = to unlock/open

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: It's cold, so please cover yourself with a blanket.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 이불을 덮다 = to cover with a blanket; 이불을 개다 = to fold the blanket

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: This pillow is very comfortable.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 베개를 베다 = to rest one's head on a pillow

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I lie on the bed and read a book.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 침 = sleep, 대 = platform; 이층 침대 = bunk bed

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I sit on the sofa and watch TV.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Also called 쇼파 in older spelling; 소파 is the standard form

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: There is a laptop on the desk.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 책 = book, 상 = table; a desk specifically for studying/working

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Please have a seat.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 의 = leaning, 자 = seat; 흔들의자 = rocking chair

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: There is a pen in the drawer.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 서랍장 = chest of drawers; 서랍을 열다/닫다 = to open/close a drawer

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I take clothes out of the wardrobe.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 옷 = clothes, 장 = cabinet; 붙박이 옷장 = built-in closet

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I open the curtains in the morning.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 커튼을 열다/치다 = to open/close curtains; 블라인드 = blinds

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I laid a carpet in the living room.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Also called 러그 (rug); 카펫을 깔다 = to lay a carpet

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I water the flowerpot.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 화 = flower, 분 = pot; 물을 주다 = to water (a plant)

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I put the family photo in a picture frame.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 액 = forehead/front, 자 = frame; 사진 액자 = photo frame

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: A clock is hanging on the wall.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 시 = time, 계 = device; 벽시계 = wall clock, 손목시계 = wristwatch

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I write appointments on the calendar.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 달 = month, 력 = record; 탁상 달력 = desk calendar

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I open the window in the morning to ventilate.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 환기하다 = to ventilate. 환기 시키다 = to air out a room. Important in Korean homes, especially during winter when rooms are sealed.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: The window screen is torn, so mosquitoes are getting in.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 방충 (防蟲, insect-proof) + 망 (網, net). Essential in Korean apartments during summer to keep bugs out while allowing airflow.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: The drain is clogged, so the water won't go down.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 배수 (排水, drain water) + 구 (口, opening). 배수구가 막히다 = the drain is clogged. Common issue requiring a plumber (배관공).

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Water is leaking from the faucet.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 수도 (水道, water supply) + 꼭지 (spout/tap). 물이 새다 = water leaks. 수도꼭지를 잠그다 = to turn off the faucet.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: The light bulb burned out, so I need to replace it.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 전 (電, electricity) + 구 (球, ball). 전구를 갈다 = to change a light bulb. LED 전구 is becoming the standard in Korean homes.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: The remote control batteries are dead.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 건전 (乾電, dry electric) + 지 (池, pool). Refers to disposable batteries (AA, AAA, etc.). 충전지 = rechargeable battery.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I sealed the box with tape.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Loanword from English. 스카치테이프 = scotch tape. 박스테이프 = packing tape. 테이프를 붙이다 = to put on tape.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: You need a hammer to drive a nail into the wall.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 못을 박다 = to hammer/drive a nail. 망치질하다 = to hammer. A basic tool for home maintenance.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Please tighten the screw with a screwdriver.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Loanword from English. 십자 드라이버 = Phillips screwdriver. 일자 드라이버 = flathead screwdriver.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I hammered a nail into the wall and hung a picture frame.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 못을 박다 = to drive a nail. Not to be confused with the adverb 못 (cannot). 압정 = thumbtack/pushpin.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: The screw came loose, so I need to tighten it again.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 나사를 조이다 = to tighten a screw. 나사를 풀다 = to loosen a screw. 나사가 빠지다 colloquially means someone is 'a screw loose.'

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I painted the room walls with white paint.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Loanword from English. 페인트를 칠하다 = to paint. 페인트칠 = painting (the act of). DIY painting has become popular in Korean homes.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I'm moving to a new apartment next month.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 이사하다 = to move (homes). 이사 업체/이삿짐센터 = moving company. 집들이 is the housewarming party after moving.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I did the interior design of the new house myself.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: Loanword from English. 셀프 인테리어 = DIY interior design, a growing trend in Korea. 인테리어 업체 = interior design company.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I ordered furniture online.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 가구점 = furniture store. IKEA entered the Korean market in 2014. 조립 가구 = flat-pack/assembly furniture.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example: 수납 공간이 부족해서 정리가 안 돼요.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I can't organize because there's not enough storage space.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 수납하다 = to store/put away. 수납장 = storage cabinet. 수납 정리 is a popular topic on Korean home-organizing shows.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: I mop the floor with a rag.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 걸레질하다 = to mop. 물걸레 = wet mop. 마른걸레 = dry cloth. 걸레 can also be a crude insult (use with caution).

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: A lot of dust has built up on the fan.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 먼지를 털다 = to dust off. 미세먼지 = fine dust/particulate matter, a major air quality issue in Korea.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: Mold has appeared in the bathroom.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: 곰팡이가 피다/생기다 = mold grows/appears. 곰팡이 제거제 = mold remover. Very common in humid Korean summers.

집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).example_en: There's a bug in my room and I'm scared.
집안일 & 생활 (Housework & Daily Life).notes: General term for any small insect or bug. 해충 = pest. 벌레 퇴치 = pest extermination. 바퀴벌레 = cockroach.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: The phone is broken.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 전화 = phone call, 기 = machine/device; refers to the physical device

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I bought a new cell phone.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 핸드폰 is Konglish (hand + phone); 휴대폰 is the more formal term

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Please tell me your phone number.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 번호 = number; Korean phone numbers start with 010

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I got a text message.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Short for 문자 메시지; 문자를 보내다 = to send a text

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I texted my friend.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Casual verb form of sending a text; 카톡하다 = to KakaoTalk (message)

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).english: to be on a call / to talk on the phone
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I'm on a call right now.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 통화 = phone conversation; 통화 중 = on the phone / line busy

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Please don't hang up.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Also means 'to cut off' or 'to quit'; 전화를 끊다 = to hang up the phone

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Please answer the phone.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 전화를 받다 = to answer a call; also means 'to receive' in general

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: The ringtone is too loud.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 벨 = bell, 소리 = sound; 진동 = vibration mode

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I need to charge my phone.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 충전 = charging; used for batteries, transit cards (교통카드), etc.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Did you bring a charger?
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 충전 = charging, 기 = device; 무선 충전기 = wireless charger

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: The battery is almost dead.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 배터리가 나가다/떨어지다 = battery dies; 배터리가 오래 가다 = battery lasts long

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Is there WiFi here?
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 와이파이가 되다 = WiFi is available; 와이파이에 연결하다 = to connect to WiFi

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I forgot my password.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 비밀 = secret, 번호 = number; also used for PIN codes and lock screen passwords

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I created a new account.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Used for online/app accounts; 계정을 만들다 = to create an account

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I can't log in.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 로그인하다 = to log in; 로그아웃 = logout

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I searched for it on the internet.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 검색 = search; 검색어 = search term; 검색 결과 = search results

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I downloaded this app.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 다운로드하다/다운받다 = to download; 다운받다 is more casual

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I uploaded a photo.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 업로드하다 = to upload; commonly used with 사진, 동영상, 파일

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Let's take a photo together!
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 찍다 = to take (a photo)/to stamp; 사진을 찍어 주세요 = please take a photo (for me)

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I watched a funny video.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 동 = moving, 영상 = image; 영상 is also used alone to mean video/footage

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: This app is really convenient.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Short for 애플리케이션; 앱을 깔다/설치하다 = to install an app

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I send messages through KakaoTalk.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Korea's dominant messaging app; often shortened to 카톡; 카톡하다 = to KakaoTalk

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I posted a photo on Instagram.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Often shortened to 인스타; 인스타 계정 = Instagram account

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I watch cooking videos on YouTube.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 유튜버 = YouTuber; 유튜브 채널 = YouTube channel

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I search for good restaurants on Naver.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Korea's top portal site; 네이버 지도 = Naver Maps, 네이버 블로그 = Naver Blog

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I wrote a travel review on my blog.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Very popular in Korea, especially Naver blogs for reviews and information

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I left a comment.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 댓글을 달다/쓰다 = to leave a comment; 악플 = malicious comment

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I got a lot of likes.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: From 좋다 (to be good); 좋아요를 누르다 = to press like

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I shared this post with my friend.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 공유 = sharing; used for sharing links, posts, files, etc.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I follow that singer.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 팔로우하다 = to follow; 팔로워 = follower; 언팔하다 = to unfollow

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I'm getting too many notifications.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 알리다 = to notify; 알림을 끄다 = to turn off notifications

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I change the language in settings.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 설정하다 = to set/configure; 환경 설정 = preferences/configuration

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I need to update the app.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 업데이트하다 = to update; 최신 업데이트 = latest update

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I deleted old photos.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 삭제 = deletion; used for files, messages, accounts, etc.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I saved the file.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 저장 = storage/saving; 자동 저장 = auto-save

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I copied the link.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 복사 = copy; 복사 붙여넣기 = copy and paste

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Please paste it here.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 붙이다 = to stick/attach; 붙여넣기하다 = to paste

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I sent a cute emoticon.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: In Korea, refers to large animated stickers on KakaoTalk, not just emoji

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I took a selfie and posted it.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: From 셀프 카메라 (self camera); 셀카봉 = selfie stick

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example: 데이터를 너무 많이 써서 속도가 느려졌어요.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I used too much data, so the speed slowed down.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 데이터가 떨어지다 = to run out of data. 무제한 데이터 = unlimited data.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I want to switch to a cheaper plan.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 요금 (fee/rate) + 제 (制, system). 요금제를 변경하다 = to change your plan. Korean carriers offer various 요금제 options.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Which carrier are you using?
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 통신 (communication) + 사 (社, company). Korea's big three are SK텔레콤, KT, and LG유플러스.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example: 화면이 너무 어두워요. 밝기를 올려 주세요.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: The screen is too dark. Please turn up the brightness.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 화 (畫, picture) + 면 (面, surface). 화면 보호기 = screen protector. 화면 캡처 = screenshot.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: It's safe to set a lock on your phone.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: From 잠그다 (to lock). 잠금 화면 = lock screen. 패턴 잠금 = pattern lock. 지문 잠금 = fingerprint lock.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Enter the password to unlock.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 해 (解, release) + 제 (除, remove). 잠금 해제 = unlock. 차단 해제 = unblock. Used widely in technology contexts.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: The speaker volume is too low.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 블루투스 스피커 = Bluetooth speaker. 스피커폰 = speakerphone mode.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example: 마이크가 안 돼서 통화할 수 없어요.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I can't make a call because the microphone isn't working.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 마이크를 켜다/끄다 = to turn the mic on/off. 음소거 = mute.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: The camera on this phone is really good.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 전면 카메라 = front camera. 후면 카메라 = rear camera. Koreans are very interested in camera quality.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I listen to music with earphones in.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 무선 이어폰 = wireless earbuds. 이어폰을 끼다 = to put in earphones. 헤드폰 = headphones.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I connected to the speaker via Bluetooth.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 블루투스를 켜다 = to turn on Bluetooth. 블루투스 페어링 = Bluetooth pairing.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example: 요즘 인공지능 기술이 빠르게 발전하고 있어요.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: AI technology is developing rapidly these days.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 인공 (人工, artificial) + 지능 (智能, intelligence). Often abbreviated as AI. 인공지능 스피커 = AI smart speaker.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I back up my photos to the cloud.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 클라우드 저장소 = cloud storage. 클라우드에 올리다 = to upload to the cloud.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I get too many spam messages.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 스팸 전화 = spam call. 스팸 차단 = spam blocking. Note: 스팸 also refers to the canned meat brand, very popular in Korea.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: My account was hacked, so I changed my password.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 해킹당하다 = to be hacked. 해커 = hacker. Cybersecurity is a growing concern in Korea.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: My computer got a virus.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 바이러스에 감염되다 = to be infected by a virus. 백신 프로그램 = antivirus software (Korea uses 백신 for both medical and computer viruses).

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: Make sure to back up important files.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 백업하다 = to back up. 자동 백업 = automatic backup. 백업 파일 = backup file.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I can restore the deleted files.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: 복 (復, return) + 원 (原, original). 복원하다 = to restore. 공장 초기화 = factory reset (more drastic than 복원).

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: I write my to-do list in my phone's memo app.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: Loanword from English. 메모하다 = to take a memo/note. 메모장 = notepad app. 메모지 = sticky note.

전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example: QR코드를 찍으면 메뉴를 볼 수 있어요.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).example_en: You can see the menu if you scan the QR code.
전화 & 인터넷 (Phone & Internet).notes: QR코드를 찍다/스캔하다 = to scan a QR code. Widely used in Korea for payments, menus, check-ins, and COVID-19 tracking.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wash my face and go out.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 세수하다 = to wash one's face; 얼굴이 작다 = to have a small face (a compliment in Korea)

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Your skin is really nice.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Skincare is huge in Korea; 피부 관리 = skincare; 피부과 = dermatology clinic

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I'm losing a lot of hair.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 머리 alone can mean head or hair (in context); 머리카락 specifically means hair strands

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Long hair suits you well.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 어울리다 = to suit/match; 머리가 길다 = hair is long

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I cut my hair short.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 머리를 자르다 = to cut hair; 단발머리 = bob cut

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I cut my bangs.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 앞 = front, 머리 = hair; 앞머리를 기르다 = to grow out bangs

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Your makeup looks pretty today.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 화장품 = cosmetics; 화장을 지우다 = to remove makeup

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: It takes 30 minutes to put on makeup in the morning.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 화장을 하다 is the full form; 진하게/연하게 화장하다 = heavy/light makeup

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I put on red lipstick.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 바르다 = to apply (cream, lipstick, etc.); 틴트 = lip tint (very popular in Korea)

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I apply sunscreen every day.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Also called 자외선 차단제 (UV blocking agent); essential in Korean skincare

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I can see well when I wear glasses.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 안경을 쓰다 = to wear glasses; 안경을 벗다 = to take off glasses

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear sunglasses when I go outside.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Also called 썬글라스; uses 쓰다 (to wear on head/face)

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I'm wearing contact lenses.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 렌즈를 끼다 = to put in lenses; 렌즈를 빼다 = to take out lenses

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I bought pretty earrings.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 귀 = ear, 걸이 = hanger; 귀걸이를 하다 = to wear earrings

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I received a necklace as a birthday gift.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 목 = neck, 걸이 = hanger; 목걸이를 하다 = to wear a necklace

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: The ring is so pretty.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 반지를 끼다 = to wear a ring; 결혼반지 = wedding ring

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I gave a bracelet as a gift.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 팔 = arm, 찌 = ornament; 팔찌를 차다/하다 = to wear a bracelet

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I'm wearing a new watch.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 시계를 차다 = to wear a watch; 손목시계 = wristwatch specifically

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I'm wearing a white t-shirt.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Often shortened to 티; 반팔 티 = short-sleeve tee, 긴팔 티 = long-sleeve tee

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wore a shirt to the interview.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Usually refers to a dress shirt/button-down; 남방 is an older Korean word for shirt

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: The blue blouse suits you well.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Typically a women's top; more formal/dressy than a regular 티셔츠

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I often wear dresses in summer.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Konglish from 'one piece'; in Korean it specifically means a dress

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear a suit for interviews.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 정 = proper/formal, 장 = attire; 정장을 차려입다 = to dress up in a suit

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear a jacket in autumn.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: A lighter outerwear; 자켓 is an alternate spelling

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear a long coat in winter.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Heavier than a jacket; 롱코트 = long coat, 트렌치코트 = trench coat

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: A padded jacket is essential for Korean winters.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Extremely popular in Korea; 롱패딩 = long puffer coat, a Korean winter staple

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: It was windy, so I wore a jumper.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: In Korean, refers to a casual zip-up jacket or windbreaker

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wore jeans and a t-shirt.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 청 = blue/indigo (from denim color), 바지 = pants

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear shorts when it's hot.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 반 = half, 바지 = pants; 핫팬츠 = hot pants (very short shorts)

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I change into sportswear when I exercise.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 운동 = exercise, 복 = clothes; 갈아입다 = to change clothes

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I change into pajamas and go to sleep.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 잠 = sleep, 옷 = clothes; 파자마 is also used

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I change my underwear every day.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 속 = inside/inner, 옷 = clothes; 내의 = undershirt/long underwear

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I lost one sock.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 한 짝 = one of a pair; 짝짝이 양말 = mismatched socks

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear dress shoes when I go to work.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 신다 = to wear (shoes/footwear); 구두를 닦다 = to polish dress shoes

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I often wear sneakers because they're comfortable.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 운동 = exercise, 화 = shoes; the most common casual footwear

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear slippers at home.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 실내 슬리퍼 = indoor slippers; 실외 슬리퍼 = outdoor slides

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear boots when it rains.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 레인부츠 = rain boots; 롱부츠 = tall boots; 앵클부츠 = ankle boots

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: It was raining heavily, so I wore a raincoat.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 우 = rain, 비 = cover/shelter for rain; 우산 = umbrella

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I go out wearing gloves in winter.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 장갑을 끼다 = to wear gloves; 벙어리장갑 = mittens

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear a scarf when it's cold.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 목도리 = traditional Korean term, 스카프 = loanword; 머플러 is also used

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: The pants are big, so I wear a belt.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 벨트를 매다/하다 = to wear a belt; 가죽 벨트 = leather belt

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: My father puts on a necktie and goes to work.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 넥타이를 매다 = to tie a necktie; 보타이 = bow tie

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I left my wallet at home.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 지갑을 잃어버리다 = to lose one's wallet; 카드지갑 = card holder

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Please take an umbrella.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 우산을 쓰다/펴다 = to open an umbrella; 접이식 우산 = folding umbrella

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I carry a backpack when I travel.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 배낭을 메다 = to carry a backpack; 배낭여행 = backpacking trip

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 저는 생머리라서 파마를 해 본 적이 없어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I have naturally straight hair, so I've never gotten a perm.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 생 (natural/raw) + 머리 (hair). Refers to naturally straight, unpermed hair. A classic Korean beauty standard.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I got a magic straight to straighten my curly hair.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 곱슬곱슬하다 = to be curly/wavy. 매직 스트레이트 is a popular Korean hair-straightening treatment.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I dyed my hair brown.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 염색하다 = to dye (hair). 셀프 염색 = DIY hair dyeing at home. 탈색 = bleaching. Hair salons are called 미용실 or 헤어숍.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Getting a perm totally changed the vibe.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: From 'permanent wave.' 파마를 하다 = to get a perm. 볼륨 파마 = volume perm. Korean hair salons offer many perm styles.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I've gotten a few wrinkles around my eyes.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 주름살 is another way to say wrinkles. 주름을 펴다 = to smooth out wrinkles. Anti-wrinkle skincare is huge in Korea.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I have a mole next to my nose.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 점 also means 'dot' or 'point.' 점을 빼다 = to have a mole removed. Some Koreans believe moles in certain locations carry meaning.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 어렸을 때 다쳐서 팔에 흉터가 있어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I have a scar on my arm from getting hurt as a child.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 흉 (凶, ugly/bad) + 터 (place/mark). 흉터 치료 = scar treatment. 흉터 연고 = scar cream.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 요즘 한국에서도 문신을 하는 사람이 많아요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: These days, many people in Korea also get tattoos.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 문 (文, pattern) + 신 (身, body). 타투 is also commonly used. Tattoos in Korea are legally only supposed to be done by medical doctors, though this is widely debated.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Everyone has a different body type.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 체 (體, body) + 형 (型, type). 체형에 맞는 옷 = clothes that fit your body type. 상체 = upper body, 하체 = lower body.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 너무 말라서 살을 좀 찌우고 싶어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I'm so skinny that I want to gain some weight.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Irregular verb: 마르다 → 말라요. 살이 빠지다 = to lose weight. Can be a compliment or concern depending on context.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: The baby's cheeks are chubby and cute.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: A softer, cuter way to describe someone slightly overweight. More polite than 뚱뚱하다 (fat). Often used affectionately.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I've become slim from exercising.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: A common compliment in Korea. 날씬한 몸매 = a slim figure. 몸매가 좋다 = to have a nice figure.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: That person is tall and well-built.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 건 (健, healthy) + 장 (壯, strong). Usually describes a man with a strong, muscular build. 건장한 체격 = sturdy physique.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 그 사람은 옷을 항상 세련되게 입어요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: That person always dresses stylishly.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 세련된 스타일 = sophisticated style. 도시적이다 is similar. The opposite is 촌스럽다 (tacky/unfashionable).

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example: 이 디자인이 좀 촌스러운 것 같아요.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I think this design is a bit tacky.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: From 촌 (village/rural). Implies something looks outdated or lacks style. 촌스러운 패션 = unfashionable clothing.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: That color really suits you.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Very commonly used when discussing appearance. 잘 어울려요 = it suits you well. 안 어울려요 = it doesn't suit you.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I often wear warm knit sweaters in winter.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Loanword from English 'knit.' Refers specifically to knit sweaters/knitwear. 니트를 입다 = to wear a knit sweater.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I wear a hoodie when I want to be comfortable.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: 후드 (hood) + 티 (t-shirt). A casual Korean wardrobe staple. 후드집업 = zip-up hoodie.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: I drape a cardigan over my shoulders in spring.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Loanword from English. 카디건을 걸치다 = to drape a cardigan over. Popular as a layering piece in Korean spring/autumn fashion.

외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).example_en: Wearing a vest with a suit looks cool.
외모 & 옷 (Appearance & Clothes).notes: Can refer to a formal vest or a padded vest (패딩 조끼). 구명조끼 = life vest. 등산 조끼 = hiking vest.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going to a cafe to meet a friend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: One of the first words most learners pick up. 절친 means 'best friend' (short for 절친한 친구).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My boyfriend is really good at cooking.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Literally 'male friend,' but always understood as 'boyfriend' in context. Abbreviated as 남친 in casual speech.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 여자친구 생일 선물을 아직 못 샀어요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I haven't bought a birthday gift for my girlfriend yet.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Literally 'female friend,' but means 'girlfriend.' Abbreviated as 여친 in casual speech.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My senior bought me lunch.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Used for someone who entered your school or workplace before you. An important part of Korean hierarchical culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I gave advice to my juniors.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: The counterpart of 선배. Seniors are often expected to treat juniors to meals.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: When a neighbor moves in, you greet them.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: In Korean apartments, it's common to give small gifts like toilet paper or laundry detergent to new neighbors.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: A guest is coming to our house today.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Used both for house guests and customers at a shop or restaurant. 고객 is a more formal word for 'customer.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 그 사람은 아는 사람이에요. 친구는 아니에요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That person is an acquaintance. Not a friend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Literally 'a person I know.' Koreans often distinguish clearly between 친구 (friend) and 아는 사람 (acquaintance).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 낯선 사람한테 말을 걸면 안 돼요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: You shouldn't talk to strangers.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 낯설다 means 'to be unfamiliar.' 모르는 사람 (a person I don't know) is also commonly used.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I have plans with a friend tomorrow.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Covers both 'appointment' and 'promise.' 약속을 지키다 means 'to keep a promise,' 약속을 잡다 means 'to make plans.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My friend set me up on a blind date.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: A very common way to meet potential partners in Korea. 소개 (introduction) + 미팅 (meeting) combined.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going on a date with my boyfriend this weekend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Borrowed from English. Koreans commonly celebrate the 100th day of dating (100일) as a milestone.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I don't have time for dating these days.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Refers to the general concept of being in a romantic relationship, not a single date. 연애하다 = to be in a relationship.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going to my older sister's wedding next month.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Korean weddings are usually short (about 30 minutes) and guests give money in a white envelope (축의금) as a gift.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Happy birthday! (Congratulations on your birthday!)
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 축하해요 is the most common congratulatory phrase. 축하드려요 is more polite.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I invited friends to my birthday party.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 초대 is the noun form. 초대장 means 'invitation card.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I visit my grandmother's house on weekends.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: More formal than 가다 or 놀러 가다. 놀러 가다 is used casually for 'to visit (for fun).'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: What do you want to receive as a birthday present?
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 선물하다 can also be used as a verb meaning 'to give as a gift.' Practical gifts are common in Korea.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: When you meet an elder, you greet them first.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 인사 covers greetings, goodbyes, and general polite acknowledgments. Bowing is the standard Korean greeting.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We met for the first time and shook hands.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: In Korea, when shaking hands with someone older, you support your right arm with your left hand as a sign of respect.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We met after a long time and hugged.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Hugging is less common in Korean culture than in Western cultures, especially between men. 포옹하다 = to hug.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: You use formal speech with people you meet for the first time.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Korean has distinct speech levels. Using 존댓말 with elders and strangers is essential for politeness.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I use casual speech with close friends.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Switching from 존댓말 to 반말 is a significant step in a relationship. You usually ask permission: 말 놓을까요?

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Manners are very important in Korea.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 예의 바르다 means 'to be polite/well-mannered.' 예의 없다 means 'to be rude.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: It's important to be considerate of others.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: A valued virtue in Korean society. 배려심 means 'a considerate nature.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: When you make a mistake, apologize right away.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 사과 also means 'apple' — context makes it clear. 죄송해요 and 미안해요 are the actual apology phrases.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm really grateful that my friend forgave me.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 용서해 주세요 means 'Please forgive me.' A step stronger than a simple apology.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: If you need help, please tell me.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 도움을 주다 = to give help; 도움을 받다 = to receive help. 돕다 is the verb form 'to help.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Can I ask you just one favor?
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 부탁하다 = to ask a favor. 부탁드리다 is the humble/polite version. 잘 부탁드려요 is said when asking for someone's help or cooperation.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm sorry, but I have to decline that request.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Directly refusing can feel rude in Korea. People often use softer expressions like 좀 어려울 것 같아요 (That might be difficult).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I agree with that opinion too.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 동의 is the noun form. In formal settings, 동의합니다 is used. 찬성하다 also means 'to agree/approve.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: My parents oppose that plan.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 반대 is the noun form meaning 'opposition' or 'opposite.' 반대쪽 means 'the opposite side.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I want to hear everyone's opinions.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 의견을 내다 = to give/offer an opinion. 의견이 다르다 = to have a different opinion.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Let's discuss this topic together.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 토론 is more formal/structured debate. 이야기하다 or 대화하다 are more casual words for 'to talk/discuss.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That's a misunderstanding. Let me explain.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 오해하다 = to misunderstand. 오해를 풀다 = to clear up a misunderstanding.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We made up quickly after fighting.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 화해 is the noun form. Often used after arguments between friends, couples, or family members.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to get along well; to be on good terms
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Everyone in our family gets along well.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Usually used as 사이가 좋다 with the subject particle. 사이가 나쁘다 means 'to not get along.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I had a fight with my friend yesterday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Can mean physical fighting or verbal arguing depending on context. 다투다 is a softer synonym meaning 'to quarrel.'

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to break up; to part ways
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I broke up with my boyfriend last month.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Used for romantic breakups and also for parting ways with someone after meeting. Context determines meaning.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to date someone; to go out with
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: The two of them have been dating for 6 months.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 사귀다 means to be in an official relationship. 사귀자 (Let's date) is how Koreans ask someone out.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: to contact; to get in touch
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'll contact you later.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 연락 covers phone calls, texts, and messages. 연락이 안 되다 = to be unreachable. 연락처 = contact information.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I heard news about my friend after a long time.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Usually refers to personal news about someone, unlike 뉴스 which is broadcast news. 소식을 전하다 = to deliver news.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Please give my regards to your parents.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 안부를 묻다 = to ask after someone's well-being. A polite and warm expression used in Korean culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: There's a university festival this weekend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Korean university festivals (대학 축제) are famous for live performances and food stalls. 축제 분위기 = festive atmosphere.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example: 이번 주 금요일에 파티에 갈 거예요.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm going to a party this Friday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Borrowed from English. House parties are less common in Korea; Koreans more often celebrate at restaurants or karaoke rooms.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I ran into a high school classmate by chance yesterday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 동 (同, same) + 창 (窓, window — meaning same school). 동창회 = alumni reunion. 동창생 = fellow alumni.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I still keep in touch with my childhood friend.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 소꿉 refers to children playing house (소꿉놀이). A 소꿉친구 is someone you've known since early childhood.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: We've been best friends for over 10 years.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 베프 = from English 'best friend.' 절친 = short for 절친한 친구 (very close friend). Both are casual and commonly used by younger Koreans.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That person is a work acquaintance.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 지 (知, know) + 인 (人, person). More formal than 아는 사람. 지인 소개 = introduction through an acquaintance.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: It's important to meet a good mentor.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Loanword from English. 멘티 = mentee. 멘토링 = mentoring. The 멘토-멘티 relationship is valued in Korean work culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).english: benefactor / someone you owe gratitude to
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That person is my life's benefactor.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 은 (恩, grace/kindness) + 인 (人, person). 생명의 은인 = someone who saved your life. A strong, emotional term in Korean.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: That athlete is a long-time rival.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Loanword from English. Can be used positively (healthy competition) or negatively. 라이벌 관계 = rivalry.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I'm a passionate fan of that singer.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: Loanword from English. 팬클럽 = fan club. 팬미팅 = fan meeting. 팬심 = a fan's devotion/heart. Korea has a very organized fan culture.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I made a library membership card.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 회 (會, association) + 원 (員, person). 회원 가입 = membership registration. 회원증 = membership card.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I got a Korean language proficiency certificate.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 자격 (qualification) + 증 (證, proof). 자격증을 따다 = to earn a certificate. Koreans often collect multiple 자격증 for career advancement.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I do volunteer work every Saturday.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 봉사활동 = volunteer activities. 봉사자 = volunteer. Korean students often need 봉사 hours for school records.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I donated for neighbors in need.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 기부하다 = to donate. 기부금 = donation (money). 기부 문화 = donation culture. 연말 기부 = year-end donations.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: I went to vote on election day.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 투표하다 = to vote. 투표소 = polling station. 투표율 = voter turnout. Korea holds presidential elections every 5 years.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Tax is deducted from my salary.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 세 (稅, tax) + 금 (金, money). 소득세 = income tax. 부가가치세 = VAT. 세금을 내다 = to pay taxes.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: It's important to follow the law.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 법 (法, law). 법률 is more formal. 법원 = court. 변호사 = lawyer. 법을 어기다 = to break the law.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: You must follow the classroom rules well.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 규 (規, standard) + 칙 (則, rule). 규칙을 지키다 = to follow rules. 규칙을 어기다 = to break rules. 규정 is a more formal synonym.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Citizens gathered for environmental protection.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 시 (市, city) + 민 (民, people). 시민권 = citizenship. 시민의식 = civic consciousness. 시민단체 = civic organization.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: All people have equal rights.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 권 (權, power) + 리 (利, benefit). 인권 = human rights. 권리를 행사하다 = to exercise one's rights.

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Paying taxes is a citizen's duty.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 의 (義, righteousness) + 무 (務, duty). 의무적 = obligatory/mandatory. 국방의 의무 = duty of national defense (Korean men serve mandatory military service).

관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).example_en: Gender equality is a very important value.
관계 & 사회 (Relationships & Society).notes: 평 (平, flat/equal) + 등 (等, grade/rank). 평등하다 = to be equal. 불평등 = inequality. 성평등 = gender equality.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Is anyone there? Help!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: The most important phrase to know in an emergency. 도와주다 = to help (someone). 살려 주세요! is used for life-threatening situations.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: It's dangerous if you go there! Be careful!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 위험하다 = to be dangerous. 위험 is the noun form. 조심하세요 (Be careful) is a commonly paired phrase.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Fire! Get out quickly!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: This is shouted in 반말 even in emergencies because speed matters more than politeness. 불 = fire.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: We need to report it to the police.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 경찰서 = police station. 경찰관 = police officer. Dial 112 in Korea to reach the police.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: The firefighters put out the fire quickly.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소방서 = fire station. 소방차 = fire truck. Korean firefighters also handle medical emergencies.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please call an ambulance quickly!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 구급차를 부르다 = to call an ambulance. In Korea, call 119 for both fire and ambulance services.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If there's an accident, call 119.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Korea's emergency number for fire and medical emergencies. Equivalent to 911 in the US. Available 24/7.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you saw a thief, report it to 112.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Korea's police emergency number. For non-emergency police matters, visit the local 경찰서 (police station).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: There was a traffic accident on the road.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 교통사고 = traffic accident. 사고가 나다 = an accident occurs. 사고를 당하다 = to be in an accident.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you're sick at night, go to the emergency room.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 응급 = emergency, 실 = room. Korean hospitals usually have 24-hour emergency rooms. 응급 환자 = emergency patient.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: A thief stole my wallet.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소매치기 = pickpocket. 강도 = robber (more violent). 도둑을 잡다 = to catch a thief.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I went to the lost and found center and asked.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 분실물 = lost item. 분실 신고 = report of a lost item. Korea has excellent lost and found systems, especially on public transit.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I lost my phone on the subway.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 잃어버리다 is for losing objects. 길을 잃다 = to get lost (lose your way). 잃다 alone is more literary.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I found the bag I lost!
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Can mean both 'to look for' and 'to find.' Context determines meaning. 찾아보다 emphasizes the searching process.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you see a suspicious person, please report it.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Used for reporting to police, fire department, etc. 신고 = report. 신고 접수 = report received.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If there's an earthquake, evacuate outside.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 대피소 = shelter/evacuation site. 대피 훈련 = evacuation drill. Very important during natural disasters.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Check the location of the emergency exit in advance.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 비상 = emergency, 구 = exit/opening. Green exit signs in Korea are marked 비상구. Required in all public buildings.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: You need to know how to use a fire extinguisher.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소화 = extinguishing fire. Red fire extinguishers are placed in hallways of most Korean buildings.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: There was a small earthquake last night.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 지진이 나다 = an earthquake occurs. Korea has occasional earthquakes. The 2017 Pohang earthquake raised awareness significantly.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: It rained a lot and there was a flood.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 홍수 주의보 = flood warning. Korea's monsoon season (장마철) in summer can bring heavy flooding.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: There was a power outage because of the typhoon.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 정전되다 = for power to go out. 전기가 나가다 is a more casual way to say the same thing.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: The elevator broke down.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 고장 나다 = to break down. 고장 수리 = repair. Signs saying 고장 mean 'out of order.'

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I signed up for insurance before my trip.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 여행자 보험 = travel insurance. 건강 보험 = health insurance. Korea has a national health insurance system (국민건강보험).

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Make sure to bring your passport.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 여권 번호 = passport number. 여권을 갱신하다 = to renew a passport. Keep it safe while traveling in Korea.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: You need a visa to study in Korea.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 관광 비자 = tourist visa. 학생 비자 = student visa. 비자를 받다 = to receive a visa.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please show me your ID.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: Korean citizens carry a 주민등록증 (resident registration card) issued at age 17. Foreigners carry an 외국인등록증.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: If you lose your passport, go to the consulate.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 대사관 = embassy (in the capital). 영사관 = consulate (in other cities). Both can help citizens abroad.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I need Korean interpretation.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 통역사 = interpreter. 통역하다 = to interpret. Refers specifically to spoken language, unlike 번역 which is written.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please translate this document into English.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 번역가 = translator. 번역하다 = to translate. Refers to written translation, unlike 통역 which is spoken.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).english: to make an appointment; to set up plans
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I made an appointment at the hospital.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 약속 = appointment/promise, 잡다 = to catch/set. Also used casually for making plans with friends.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I'll make a reservation at the restaurant before going.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 예약 = reservation. 예약이 꽉 찼어요 = Reservations are fully booked. Used for restaurants, hotels, hospitals, etc.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I canceled my plans because it rained.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 취소 = cancellation. 취소 수수료 = cancellation fee. 주문을 취소하다 = to cancel an order.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: I want to change my flight date.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: More formal than 바꾸다 (to change). 변경 = change/modification. 일정 변경 = schedule change.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please confirm the reservation one more time.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 확인 = confirmation. Very commonly used in daily life. 확인했어요 = I checked/confirmed it.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please sign here.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 서명 = signature. 사인 (from English 'sign') is also widely used in casual contexts. 도장 = stamp/seal, used alongside signatures in Korea.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: It's good to learn first aid methods.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 응급 (emergency) + 처치 (treatment). 응급처치 키트 = first aid kit.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Do you know how to perform CPR?
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 심폐 (heart and lungs) + 소생술 (resuscitation technique). Often abbreviated as CPR even in Korean.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Please wrap the wound with a bandage.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 감다 = to wrap/wind. 붕대를 감다 is the standard collocation.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Apply disinfectant to the wound first.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 소독 (disinfection) + 약 (medicine). 소독하다 = to disinfect.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: They move the patient on a stretcher.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 들다 (to carry) + 것 (thing). Used by paramedics and in hospitals.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: What's your blood type? I'm type A.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 혈액 (blood) + 형 (type). In Korea, blood type is a popular topic, believed to relate to personality.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example: 수술 중에 수혈이 필요할 수 있어요.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: A blood transfusion may be needed during surgery.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 수 (to receive/give) + 혈 (blood). 수혈하다 = to give/receive a transfusion.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: My father was hospitalized.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 입 (enter) + 원 (hospital). 입원하다 = to be hospitalized. Opposite of 퇴원.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: They said I can be discharged next week.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 퇴 (retreat/leave) + 원 (hospital). 퇴원하다 = to be discharged.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: After the test, I was diagnosed with a cold.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 진단하다 = to diagnose, 진단받다 = to be diagnosed. 진단서 = medical certificate.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: The doctor gave me a prescription.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 처방하다 = to prescribe, 처방전 = prescription paper. Take the 처방전 to the pharmacy.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example: 이 약은 부작용이 있을 수 있어요.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: This medication may have side effects.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 부 (secondary) + 작용 (effect). Common question at pharmacies: 부작용이 있어요?

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: This area is off-limits.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 금지하다 = to prohibit. Common signs: 주차 금지, 촬영 금지, 흡연 금지.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: Be careful because it's slippery.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 주의하다 = to be careful/cautious. Seen on warning signs everywhere.

긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).example_en: You cannot bring hazardous materials onto the plane.
긴급 상황 & 안전 (Emergencies & Safety).notes: 위험 (danger) + 물 (thing/material). 위험물 취급 주의 = handle hazardous materials with care.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I wear hanbok on Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Korea's traditional clothing, now worn mainly on holidays and special occasions. Many tourists rent hanbok near palaces for free entry.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We make kimchi before winter comes.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: An important annual tradition, usually in November. Families and communities gather to make large batches of kimchi for winter. UNESCO recognized it as cultural heritage.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We eat rice cake soup on the morning of Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Eating 떡국 on 설날 symbolizes gaining one year of age. The sliced rice cakes resemble coins, representing prosperity.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We make songpyeon together with family on Chuseok.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Half-moon shaped rice cakes filled with sesame, beans, or chestnuts. Made together as a family tradition during Chuseok.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We bow to our elders for the New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A deep bow performed on 설날 to show respect to elders. After bowing, elders give wisdom, blessings, and 세뱃돈 (money).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I bowed and received New Year's money.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Money given by elders to children and young people after 세배. Usually given in clean, crisp bills inside an envelope.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: On Chuseok, we go to our hometown.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: One of Korea's biggest holidays (August 15th on the lunar calendar). Families gather, visit ancestral graves, and share food. Expect heavy traffic.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: The whole family gathers on Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: January 1st on the lunar calendar. Along with 추석, it is one of Korea's two most important holidays. A 3-day holiday period.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 한글날은 한글을 만든 것을 기념하는 날이에요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Hangul Day is a day to celebrate the creation of Hangul.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Celebrates King Sejong's creation of the Korean alphabet in 1443. A national holiday since 2013.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We give carnations to our parents on Parents' Day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Unlike separate Mother's/Father's Days in other countries, Korea celebrates both parents on one day. Carnations are the traditional gift.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We go to the amusement park on Children's Day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A national holiday where parents spend the day with their children. Amusement parks, zoos, and kid-friendly places are very crowded.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: There are many beautiful hanok in Bukchon.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Traditional houses with curved roofs and 온돌 (heated floors). 북촌한옥마을 and 전주한옥마을 are famous hanok villages.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 한국 집에는 온돌이 있어서 바닥이 따뜻해요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean houses have ondol so the floor is warm.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A traditional Korean heating system where hot air flows under the floor. Modern apartments still use this principle. Koreans often sit and sleep on heated floors.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I spent a night at the jjimjilbang with friends.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A large public bathhouse with saunas, heated rooms, and common areas. Open 24 hours; popular for overnight stays. You wear provided shorts and a t-shirt.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We went to karaoke after the company dinner.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Private singing rooms, not open-stage karaoke. A staple of Korean nightlife and socializing. 코인노래방 has coin-operated machines for solo singing.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Having chicken and beer at the Han River is the best.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 치킨 (chicken) + 맥주 (beer) = 치맥. A beloved Korean combo, especially popular to eat outdoors along the Han River.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Shall I make you a glass of somaek?
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 소주 (soju) + 맥주 (beer) = 소맥. A popular way to drink in Korea. The ideal ratio is debated, but 3:7 (soju:beer) is common.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: In Korea, anything can be delivered.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Korea has one of the world's most advanced delivery cultures. Food, groceries, and almost anything can be delivered quickly via apps like 배달의민족 and 쿠팡이츠.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I bought a triangle kimbap at the convenience store.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Korea has an extremely high density of convenience stores (CU, GS25, 세븐일레븐). They sell meals, snacks, and even have seating areas.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: People with quick nunchi are popular.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A core Korean social concept — the ability to read the atmosphere and others' feelings. 눈치가 빠르다 = quick nunchi (good), 눈치가 없다 = no nunchi (bad).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We've worked together a long time, so I've developed jeong.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: An untranslatable Korean concept — a deep emotional bond formed through shared experience. 정이 들다 = to develop jeong. 정이 많다 = to be warm-hearted.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: It's important to show filial piety to your parents.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A Confucian value deeply embedded in Korean culture. 효도하다 = to practice filial piety. 효자 = devoted son, 효녀 = devoted daughter.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: In Korea, the senior-junior culture is strong.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: The hierarchical system based on age and experience in school and work. 선배 (senior) is expected to guide and treat 후배 (junior).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: There's a company dinner tonight.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: After-work team dinners, often involving multiple rounds (1차, 2차, 3차). Traditionally mandatory, but becoming more optional in modern Korean workplaces.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I rode a bicycle at Han River Park on the weekend.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: The river flowing through Seoul with beautiful parks along both banks. Popular for picnics, cycling, and ordering delivery food (한강 배달).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I saw the Seoul night view from Namsan Tower.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: An iconic landmark on Namsan Mountain in Seoul. Famous for its observation deck and the 'love locks' left by couples on the fence.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I took photos wearing hanbok at Gyeongbokgung.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: The main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty, built in 1395. Free entry if wearing hanbok. The guard-changing ceremony is a popular attraction.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 제주도는 한국에서 가장 인기 있는 여행지예요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Jeju Island is the most popular travel destination in Korea.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A volcanic island off the southern coast of Korea. Famous for 한라산 (Hallasan), 돌하르방 (stone statues), and beautiful nature. A UNESCO World Heritage site.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 경주에 가면 불국사에 꼭 가 보세요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: If you go to Gyeongju, definitely visit Bulguksa.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A UNESCO World Heritage Buddhist temple in Gyeongju, built in 774. One of Korea's most famous historical sites, representing Silla dynasty architecture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Samulnori performances are really exciting.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Traditional percussion music using four instruments: 꽹과리 (small gong), 징 (large gong), 장구 (hourglass drum), and 북 (barrel drum).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Pansori is a UNESCO cultural heritage.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A traditional Korean art form where a single singer performs a long narrative with a drummer. UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage since 2003.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Taekwondo is Korea's representative martial art.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Korea's national martial art and an Olympic sport since 2000. Emphasizes kicks. 도장 = training hall. 띠 = belt (rank).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I went to a Korean medicine clinic because my back hurt.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한의학 = Korean traditional medicine. Treatments include 침 (acupuncture), 한약 (herbal medicine), and 부항 (cupping). Covered by national health insurance.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I go to the sauna after exercising.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Many Korean gyms and bathhouses have saunas. Often used interchangeably with 목욕탕 in casual speech, though they differ.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I went to the neighborhood bathhouse and got a scrub.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Traditional public baths found in every neighborhood. 때밀이 (body scrub) is a signature service. A key part of Korean bathing culture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I played games at the PC room with friends.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Gaming cafes with high-end PCs. Very popular in Korea, especially for online games. Usually open 24 hours with food and drink service.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: This is ten thousand won.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 만 (10,000) is the basic large unit in Korean currency. 만원 bills are the most commonly used denomination. About 7-8 USD.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 요즘 아이돌 콘서트 표가 너무 비싸요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: K-pop idol concert tickets are so expensive these days.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Members of K-pop groups. Korea's idol culture includes 팬미팅 (fan meetings), 응원봉 (light sticks), and organized fan communities.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: What K-drama are you watching these days?
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Korean TV dramas, hugely popular worldwide. Usually 16 episodes. 한국 드라마 is the full form. Streaming platforms like Netflix have boosted global popularity.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korea is famous for its 'hurry hurry' culture.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A defining aspect of Korean culture — everything moves fast: delivery, internet, construction, service. Reflects Korea's rapid modernization and work ethic.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 한류 덕분에 한국어를 배우는 사람이 많아요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Thanks to the Korean Wave, many people are learning Korean.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한 (韓, Korea) + 류 (流, wave/flow). Refers to the global popularity of Korean culture including K-pop, K-dramas, and Korean food.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: K-pop is popular all around the world.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Korean pop music. Major groups include BTS, BLACKPINK, and many more. 케이팝 팬덤 = K-pop fandom.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I eat Korean food every day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한 (韓, Korea) + 식 (食, food). 한식당 = Korean restaurant. 양식 = Western food. 일식 = Japanese food. 중식 = Chinese food.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean traditional medicine considers body balance important.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 한 (韓, Korean) + 의학 (醫學, medicine). Includes acupuncture (침), herbal medicine (한약), and cupping (부항). Covered by national health insurance.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 풍수에 따라 집을 배치하는 사람도 있어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Some people arrange their homes according to feng shui.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 풍 (風, wind) + 수 (水, water). 풍수지리 is the full term. Historically influenced Korean city planning and grave placement.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: My grandfather is good at calligraphy.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 서 (書, writing) + 예 (藝, art). Practiced with 붓 (brush) and 먹 (ink). Still taught in some Korean schools as cultural education.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean pottery is world-famous.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 도 (陶, pottery) + 자 (磁, porcelain) + 기 (器, vessel). 고려청자 (Goryeo celadon) is a famous Korean ceramic style. 이천 is Korea's pottery capital.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: They sell lots of delicious food at the traditional market.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 전통 (traditional) + 시장 (market). Famous markets include 남대문시장, 광장시장, and 자갈치시장. A great place to experience Korean food culture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Korean Buddhism has a very long history.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 불 (佛, Buddha) + 교 (教, teaching). Korea has many famous Buddhist temples. 템플스테이 (temple stay) is a popular cultural experience for visitors.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 유교 문화가 한국 사회에 큰 영향을 줬어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Confucian culture has had a big influence on Korean society.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 유 (儒, Confucian) + 교 (教, teaching). 유교적 가치관 = Confucian values. Influenced Korean emphasis on education, respect for elders, and family loyalty.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Elders give words of blessing on Lunar New Year.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 덕 (德, virtue) + 담 (談, talk). Elders share encouraging words after 세배. Examples: 건강하거라 (be healthy), 공부 잘하거라 (study well).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I was invited to a baby's first birthday party.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 돌 (first birthday) + 잔치 (feast/party). A major celebration where the baby picks objects (돌잡이) to predict their future. Very elaborate in Korean culture.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We held a 60th birthday celebration for my father.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 환 (還, return) + 갑 (甲, first). Marks completing the 60-year zodiac cycle. Traditionally a huge celebration; now less extravagant but still honored.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: Bossam is delicious when eaten with kimchi.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Boiled pork belly wrapped in napa cabbage or perilla leaves with kimchi and other condiments. A popular dish to share with drinks.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 비 오는 날에 막걸리를 마시고 싶어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I want to drink makgeolli on a rainy day.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: A milky, slightly sweet fermented rice wine. 막걸리와 파전 (makgeolli with Korean pancake) is a classic rainy-day combo.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example: 이번 달 반상회에서 주차 문제를 이야기했어요.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: We discussed the parking problem at this month's neighborhood meeting.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 반 (班, group) + 상 (常, regular) + 회 (會, meeting). Regular meetings held in apartment complexes to discuss community issues.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: There are many good cafes in our neighborhood.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 동네 사람 = neighborhood person. 동네 맛집 = neighborhood favorite restaurant. More casual and warm-sounding than 지역 (area/region).

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: An ajumma sells fruit cheaply at the market.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Refers to a married or middle-aged woman. Can sound rude depending on context. 아주머니 is the polite form. 이모 (aunt) is a friendlier alternative.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: The ajusshi next door is very kind.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: Refers to a middle-aged man. 삼촌 (uncle) is sometimes used as a friendlier alternative by children. 아저씨 can make younger men feel old.

한국 문화 (Korean Culture).example_en: I live in an officetel near my office.
한국 문화 (Korean Culture).notes: 오피스 (office) + 호텔 (hotel). A Korean-style studio apartment, often in commercial buildings. Popular with single young professionals in cities.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I'm going on a trip to Jeju Island this summer.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: Can be used as a noun or combined with 하다 (여행하다) to make a verb.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: There are really many places to sightsee in Seoul.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: More formal than 구경하다 (to look around). Often used in compound nouns like 관광객 (tourist).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I booked a package tour at the travel agency.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 사 (社) means company/agency. Common pattern: 회사 (company), 출판사 (publisher).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example: 호텔 예약은 미리 하는 게 좋아요.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: It's good to make hotel reservations in advance.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 예약하다 = to reserve/book. 미리 = in advance, a useful companion word.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: You can see the ocean from this hotel.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: Loanword from English. Korean-style lodging options include 모텔, 민박, 펜션.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I met people from many countries at the guesthouse.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: Popular budget accommodation in Korea, especially in tourist areas like Hongdae and Busan.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I stayed at a homestay in the countryside.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: A traditional Korean lodging where you stay in a local home. Common in rural and coastal areas.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Check-in is available from 3 PM.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: Loanword used at hotels and airports. 체크인하다 = to check in.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What time is check-out?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 체크아웃하다 = to check out. Usually 11 AM or 12 PM at Korean hotels.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The room is spacious and clean.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: Also used in compounds: 방값 (room rate), 빈방 (vacant room), 화장실 (bathroom, lit. makeup room).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please leave the room key at the front desk.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: Modern hotels use 카드키 (card key). 열쇠 comes from 열다 (to open).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The luggage is too heavy.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 짐을 싸다 = to pack luggage. 짐을 풀다 = to unpack.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: The suitcase wheel broke.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: From English 'carrier.' In Korea this specifically means a rolling suitcase. 여행 가방 is also used.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I put my passport in my bag.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: General word for bag. 핸드백 (handbag), 백팩 (backpack), 서류 가방 (briefcase).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Backpacking is nice because it's freeing.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 배낭여행 = backpacking trip. 배낭여행자 = backpacker.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please check the passport expiration date.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 여(旅) = travel, 권(券) = ticket/document. 유효기간 = expiration period.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Do I need a visa to go to Korea?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 비자를 받다 = to get a visa. 비자를 신청하다 = to apply for a visa.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: How long does it take to get to the airport?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 인천공항 (Incheon Airport) is Korea's main international airport. 김포공항 is the domestic one.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Please show your boarding pass.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 탑승(搭乘) = boarding, 권(券) = ticket. 모바일 탑승권 = mobile boarding pass.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example: 출국 수속은 2시간 전에 하는 게 좋아요.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: It's good to do departure procedures two hours in advance.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 출(出) = exit, 국(國) = country. Opposite: 입국 (entering a country).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I was asked questions at immigration.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 입국 심사 = immigration inspection. 입국 카드 = arrival card.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I went through a luggage inspection at customs.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 세관 신고서 = customs declaration form. 신고할 물건 = items to declare.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I bought gifts at the duty-free shop.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 면(免) = exempt, 세(稅) = tax. Korea has large duty-free shops at airports and downtown.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Exchange fees are cheaper if you exchange at a bank.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 환전하다 = to exchange currency. 환전소 = currency exchange booth.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: What is the exchange rate today?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 환율이 오르다 = the exchange rate goes up. 환율이 떨어지다 = the rate drops.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I got a map at the tourist information center.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 안내(案內) = guidance/information. 안내하다 = to guide. 관광 안내소 = tourist info center.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Are there any famous tourist spots nearby?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 지(地) = place. Similar: 관광 명소 (tourist attraction).

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Gyeongbokgung is a representative famous place in Seoul.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 명(名) = famous, 소(所) = place. 관광 명소 = tourist attraction.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: Can I take photos here?
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 사진을 찍다 is the full form. 셀카 찍다 = to take a selfie. 찍다 can also mean to stamp or press.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I bought a souvenir to give to my friend.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 기념(記念) = commemoration, 품(品) = item. 기념품 가게 = souvenir shop.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I found the way using a map app.
여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).notes: 네이버 지도 and 카카오맵 are more commonly used than Google Maps in Korea.

여행 & 관광 (Travel & Tourism).example_en: I planned the travel itinerary.
